componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions, the first going back to the Marcellus and Utica supply to demand market context that you guys detailed. If you look at what you're doing with that Lebanon Expansion and the Marcellus to market expansion on Texas Eastern and th
componenttext: A couple of quick questions, the first going back to the Marcellus and Utica supply to demand market context that you guys detailed. If you look at what you're doing with that Lebanon Expansion and the Marcellus to market expansion on Texas Eastern and then, of course, in Philadelphia, obviously, there's some variability in terms of CapEx spend. I'm just wondering, outside of the 100 million cubic foot a day that you detailed that the Lebanon Project could represent, what do you think the scale and scope of those expansions ultimately would be? And from a time-to-market perspective, just based on the competitive landscape and certainly the oversupply in the area, do you think that there's any opportunity for maybe those to get the greenlight added to backlog quicker and, from a net present value basis, be more of a benefit for future organic growth to come?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's Bill Yardley. I think I got most of those questions. So in terms of the scale and the scope of the projects that we have an origination now, there is a fair amount of variability. Philly is probably the biggest variable. We've identified a re
componenttext: Yes. So it's Bill Yardley. I think I got most of those questions. So in terms of the scale and the scope of the projects that we have an origination now, there is a fair amount of variability. Philly is probably the biggest variable. We've identified a really good lift and relay project down the Philly Lateral. That's probably an area that's next in line in our system as the most constrained beyond New York, which, of course, we solved a couple of years ago. And New England, which we're well on the way to solving with these 3 projects, AIM, Atlantic Bridge and Access Northeast, Philly is probably the next biggest constrained area. But we probably have a project that's in the $1 billion range, maybe 0.5 Bcf a day to the Philly load. And we'll see the season brings on May 8. To your question on getting things in service quicker, we -- I think we all know the regulatory process and the permitting process isn't getting any easier as time goes on nor is it any easier as you head north and east in the U.S. So difficult to see where we can get things in quicker, but I do think we have realistic time lines on these projects.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darren, also, those projects really underline the fact that a lot of this really isn't greenfield. And one of the real advantages, as we've often said, is being where the lights are, and Bill's projects and the work his guys are doing really accentua
componenttext: Yes. Darren, also, those projects really underline the fact that a lot of this really isn't greenfield. And one of the real advantages, as we've often said, is being where the lights are, and Bill's projects and the work his guys are doing really accentuate that. So some of the projects might be relatively small CapEx, but very powerful obviously for our customers. And then some other projects like the Philly Lateral would be significant builds -- but you got it right. It's a tough area.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it makes the world of sense, and Bill, I'd love your opinion, but it seems like, especially when you talk about Access Northeast, leveraging your footprint with Algonquin and M&N, I think is a significant advantage, correct me if I'm wrong,
componenttext: Well, I think it makes the world of sense, and Bill, I'd love your opinion, but it seems like, especially when you talk about Access Northeast, leveraging your footprint with Algonquin and M&N, I think is a significant advantage, correct me if I'm wrong, that you would have with regard to some of the other competing pipes and certainly from a regulatory perspective. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It certainly is. And really, without talking about competitors, I mean, we've looked at greenfield in the area and the fact is this is a peak problem, number one. So you don't want overbuild the summer. And then number two, you got to get -- you got
componenttext: Yes. It certainly is. And really, without talking about competitors, I mean, we've looked at greenfield in the area and the fact is this is a peak problem, number one. So you don't want overbuild the summer. And then number two, you got to get -- you got to take advantage of whatever resources you have there, both from a stakeholder outreach perspective, from a timing perspective and right size the development for the -- to meet the market needs and get solid returns.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate it. If I could just also switch real quickly, just to Express-Platte. Outside of the $135 million project that you talked about from an on-system enhancement perspective, any update regarding your pursuit of twinning the system or just
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate it. If I could just also switch real quickly, just to Express-Platte. Outside of the $135 million project that you talked about from an on-system enhancement perspective, any update regarding your pursuit of twinning the system or just the ability, especially with where differentials are today, the ability to move, like you've mentioned, Canadian Rockies, Bakken crude to the Midwest, maybe rescoping the Wyoming line. It just seems like the economic incentive is only going to get greater, I think, as we deal with supply-demand imbalances and it would seem like that would be more in the forefront.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, definitely, the team is working on those. As you know, the challenge, I'll call it, we've had recent oil at $60, but typically in the first quarter closer to $50. Even with the differential, I think that you still have a number of producers,
componenttext: Right. Well, definitely, the team is working on those. As you know, the challenge, I'll call it, we've had recent oil at $60, but typically in the first quarter closer to $50. Even with the differential, I think that you still have a number of producers, Darren, reeling from uncertainty. And some of those projects, they start to get pretty sizable from a CapEx perspective, particularly on the twinning side and would take decade-plus commitments. And I think producers have just been very hesitant to do that. That being said, I think we continue -- you'll see us continue to push enhancement-type projects as well as the major projects. I think the issue is not if, it's just when. So from a timing perspective, obviously, if you do a twinning, that has much different regulatory implications than if you are just doing enhancements to basically get up to the existing capacity. But we're looking to work with other partners. We're looking to do enhancements and even greenfield, if necessary, to meet the customer needs. But I think the type of projects you see, like the enhancement where you add 25,000 or 30,000 barrels a day, is much more in line with what producers are willing to sign up today. So every month we see an increase in the price of oil, I think the likelihood of those projects coming back fully on the radar screen and, we believe, that will definitely allow us to secure those big projects before the end of the decade.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: Yes. So on the Lebanon project, it would be supplier push. Marcellus to market, mostly supplier push. And then Philly is likely to be a combination. The Philly area really has a number of customers that are trying to figure out how to get more energy into that area, and so I would bet on a fair amount of demand pull there.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then moving to a different part of the continent. Western Canadian propane, less than $0.10 a gallon. Are there any opportunities for kind of near-term incremental infrastructure to relieve that supply problem?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then moving to a different part of the continent. Western Canadian propane, less than $0.10 a gallon. Are there any opportunities for kind of near-term incremental infrastructure to relieve that supply problem?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's less of a -- no, we have not seen a big desire. Again, in some respect, it's kind of like the oil side. People are waiting to see what the long-term price signals are. So that continues be a challenge. There is some activity on the rail
componenttext: Well, I think it's less of a -- no, we have not seen a big desire. Again, in some respect, it's kind of like the oil side. People are waiting to see what the long-term price signals are. So that continues be a challenge. There is some activity on the rail side as you probably know. But you point out a good fact and the supplies aren't going down in terms of the volumes of gas. In fact, it's probably surprising to a lot of people. April saw Western Canada produce 15 Bs [ph] a day, which is the probably -- which is the highest production rate in a decade -- or 8 to 10 years. So we'll look at those. I think again the issue is at those prices, as you can imagine folks like ourselves, the margins are extremely small, hence, our likelihood of earning more like $30 million in cash as opposed to what we've seen in some of the other years. So opportunity there, I think the price signals suggest that people probably don't want to commit for those long term. But again, just like on the oil side, I think it's matter of if not when -- or sorry, when, not if.

componenttext: Greg, could you just talk a little bit further on the Access Northeast? I mean, is there a way you can sort of quantify, I guess, the competitive advantage you think you might have with Eversource and National Grid and -- because, obviously, you've got the competing proposal out there?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- I'll start and then Bill can add to that. I think the #1 competitive advantage is the one you just point to with Eversource and Grid. As we've been talking about a little bit on this call, John, is that you know how difficult it is to pla
componenttext: Well, I think -- I'll start and then Bill can add to that. I think the #1 competitive advantage is the one you just point to with Eversource and Grid. As we've been talking about a little bit on this call, John, is that you know how difficult it is to place assets into service. We take great pride on the fact that we've been in those areas for half a century or so. But the Eversource and Grid folks have been there even longer and this is a ground game, and being able to understand the needs, how to use existing assets to maximize capabilities and yet minimize new infrastructure is a real advantage to have those folks along. And then, of course, we would expect them to help support the pipeline through contracts as well. And ultimately, there needs to be, beyond the FERC approvals, there needs to be state approvals on some of this and they obviously have probably the best insight from that perspective. So volume, in terms of 4.8 million versus 6.5 million on the ground, existing assets, working as partnership, regulatory and our ability to put pipes in the ground, all add up to, we think, check, check, check from a competitive perspective, our pipeline proposals versus some others.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And also, I take it then your thought is there's really going to be one winner here. There's not going to be a second player. It's going to be one or the other, correct?
componenttext: And also, I take it then your thought is there's really going to be one winner here. There's not going to be a second player. It's going to be one or the other, correct?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Here's how I would answer that question. When Access Northeast is built, it will not be the end of needs in New England. Over time, with the projects we're building, AIM and Atlantic Bridge, we're not even touching the electric market. Access is the first
componenttext: Here's how I would answer that question. When Access Northeast is built, it will not be the end of needs in New England. Over time, with the projects we're building, AIM and Atlantic Bridge, we're not even touching the electric market. Access is the first one we're touching in the electric market. And over the last winter, it's probably cost consumers up there, during at least 2 winters, $2 billion plus in costs and Access Northeast is not going to relieve all that. So there will be a need for additional projects. I guess, I would put it this way. Access Northeast will be the first of what I expect to be many continuing infrastructure needs on the gas side in New England.

componenttext: Maybe we'll continue flogging Access Northeast once more. It is really just, Greg, to your comment of expecting to put this in execution later this year. Is the gating item here just having the NESCOE process run its course? And if that's the case, is there any insight as to when you think that happens?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think it's necessarily NESCOE as opposed to just making sure that we're all on the same page that whatever regulatory approval for contracts and rates actually make very good progress and get done. So I think the state approvals of rate struc
componenttext: Yes. I don't think it's necessarily NESCOE as opposed to just making sure that we're all on the same page that whatever regulatory approval for contracts and rates actually make very good progress and get done. So I think the state approvals of rate structure is probably a bigger issue than NESCOE.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- Carl, it's Bill. I think you've got to figure this is a solution that's designed specifically to fit what NESCOE was contemplating as they went through the winter. And when you look at that and think about what we're trying to do here is t
componenttext: Yes. I think -- Carl, it's Bill. I think you've got to figure this is a solution that's designed specifically to fit what NESCOE was contemplating as they went through the winter. And when you look at that and think about what we're trying to do here is trying to get all the states, which are frankly lined up pretty well right now from a cooperative standpoint, to make sure that they've got the right mechanisms in place to approve contracts that are signed by electric distribution companies. And within the 6 New England states, Greg hit it on the nose. You've got -- between Eversource and National Grid, you got between 2/3 and 100% of the electric customers in 4 of those 6 states saying they want Access Northeast. So this process, I think, I'm very confident that we're going to be getting into service or rather into execution later this year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Does that require legislation sort of by the -- by -- I mean, as far as to meet that service date, call it, by the end of this year? Or do you see momentum of that building sooner rather than later?
componenttext: Does that require legislation sort of by the -- by -- I mean, as far as to meet that service date, call it, by the end of this year? Or do you see momentum of that building sooner rather than later?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say sooner rather than later. I think it's a mix bag in New England. You've got some states that I think are fairly sure they can make those approvals now. And you've got other states that are saying, okay, how do we work towards getting that
componenttext: Yes. I would say sooner rather than later. I think it's a mix bag in New England. You've got some states that I think are fairly sure they can make those approvals now. And you've got other states that are saying, okay, how do we work towards getting that together? You know the process in Maine has been through an energy cost reduction plan. And still, other states will have yet other mechanisms, perhaps one requiring legislation. But I think the good news is when the governors met last month, there was a pretty good agreement that this is the direction we want to head in and let's work to get this done as soon as we can.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excellent. I appreciate the color. And maybe one just sort of final question. Greg, given your prior sphere of Canadian politics, I'm just curious, the NDP win yesterday in Alberta, does that change anything for you all as you're looking at Western Canada
componenttext: Excellent. I appreciate the color. And maybe one just sort of final question. Greg, given your prior sphere of Canadian politics, I'm just curious, the NDP win yesterday in Alberta, does that change anything for you all as you're looking at Western Canada with some of the challenges that may come because of it?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I actually -- as you know, most of our business in Western Canada is in British Columbia. So advantage British Columbia, should the government -- but let's give them time to see what they'll do, do things that hurt production in Alberta. We have ver
componenttext: Well, I actually -- as you know, most of our business in Western Canada is in British Columbia. So advantage British Columbia, should the government -- but let's give them time to see what they'll do, do things that hurt production in Alberta. We have very little activity in Alberta. We have a little -- as you know, we have a little bit of oil income in Alberta, but most of it's actually on the U.S. side of the border. So I think those companies whose sphere of activity is solely Alberta, I think they may find some challenges, if just from the chill effect of a change that hasn't occurred for at least 4 decades. It's just going to make people quite cautious. So we'll have to see what happens. Now that being said, Western Canada -- parts of Western Canada have seen socialist-leaning governments in the past and done okay. So we'll just -- let's give them time to figure it all out. Meanwhile, full steam ahead in British Columbia as you've seen with Jackfish and RAM and then the open season that we announced today, to make sure that we can move gas that our customers want to move out of places like the Montney to markets that need it elsewhere.

componenttext: Well, on your last one, absolutely. I think there is absolutely no daylight between Greg and Greg and Pat and Greg. And I think you heard that from them last week on their call. I don't think this is a timing that's any different than what we laid out, I think we said, sometime between April and October. And I would say a lot of really good progress during the quarter to deal with risk factors that the business is taking. Now they completed -- or launched and largely completed already some cost control measures that'll bring in reduced costs, call it, $70 million in 2016, got the revolver set up to provide flexibility and time on the structuring. They've done activity on the risk management side vis--vis hedging to third parties and yet met financial expectations in a low market. So I think we're bang on. I don't think those objectives have changed. I don't think there's any sticking points. It's a, obviously, a major entity which we both like. And we want to make sure that whatever structuring we do, we get it right, Becca. And so stay tuned and I feel very confident that April to October time frame will definitely happen.

componenttext: Good morning, my name is Angel and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Julie Dill, unit you may begin your conference call.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angel, and good morning, everyone. My name is Julie Dill, the Chief Communications Officer for Spectra Energy. Thank you for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners 2015 Second Quarter Results.With me t
componenttext:
Thank you, Angel, and good morning, everyone. My name is Julie Dill, the Chief Communications Officer for Spectra Energy. Thank you for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners 2015 Second Quarter Results.
With me today are Greg Ebel, President and CEO of both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners; and Pat Reddy, Chief Financial Officer both companies. Pat will discuss our results for the quarter and then Greg will update you on our growth opportunities and the progress we are making on our Drive to 35. And as always, we leave plenty of time for your questions.
Our safe harbor statement is contained within our presentation materials and available on our website. These disclaimer's important and integral to all our remarks, so I would ask that you refer to it as you review our materials. Also contained in our presentation materials are non-GAAP measures that we reconcile to the most strictly comparable GAAP measures. And those reconciliations are also available on our website.
So with that, let me turn things over to Pat.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered very strong ongoing EBITDA for the quarter. But before I get into the details of those re
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered very strong ongoing EBITDA for the quarter. But before I get into the details of those results, I want to discuss some special items we recorded during the quarter as shown on Slide 3.
There were 3 special items which lowered reported EBITDA by $217 million or $0.20 per share. As you can see on this slide, only 1 of these items affected DCF by $11 million. The first item is $194 million pretax, noncash charge or $122 million after-tax, which represents our 50% share of a goodwill impairment at DCP.
The second item also is associated with DCP and is a separate tax noncash charge of $12 million related to our share of a loss on the sale of an asset during the quarter.
Lastly, Western Canada recorded a pretax special item of $11 million related to employee and overhead reductions. We expect there will be some incremental charges of less than $10 million related to these efforts that will be recorded in the third and fourth quarters.
Our ongoing EBITDA increased year-over-year, so let's turn to those results, which really tell the story of the strength and resilience of our business model.
As noted, we delivered very strong second quarter results with ongoing EBITDA of $652 million at Spectra Energy and $456 million at Spectra Energy Partners. Given the current macro environment, it is significant that Spectra Energy's ongoing EBITDA increase 4% quarter-over-quarter. As we've consistently demonstrated year after year, our portfolio of asset is structured to moderate the effect of various business cycles and maximize the upside benefits. And with approximately 95% fee base earnings at U.S. Transmission that have no exposure to commodity price or volume fluctuations, SEP is a standout in the MLP space.
So let's take a look at the drivers of our results by segment. I'll start with Spectra Energy Partners, whose EBITDA was up almost 30%. SEP is comprised of our U.S. Transmission and Liquids businesses and is shown on the upper right hand corner of Slide 4. U.S. Transmission delivered EBITDA of $396 million, up $76 million. That is almost 24% higher than the same quarter last year. Results for the 2015 quarter were driven primarily by increased earnings from expansion projects placed into service, specifically, TEAM 2014, TEAM South and the Kingsport project.
Our Liquids business reported second quarter EBITDA of $78 million compared with $51 million in 2014. The increase was primarily driven by higher volumes and tariffs on the Express crude pipeline, as well as higher equity earnings from increased volumes on the Sand Hills natural gas liquids pipeline. As you can see, SEP is performing very well and delivering results ahead of our expectations.
Moving to the table on the left-hand side of this slide, distribution reported second quarter EBITDA of $98 million compared to $512 million in 2014. The decrease quarter-over-quarter was due almost entirely to the decline in the value of the Canadian dollar, which was down 13% this quarter compared with 2014.
Western Canada recorded ongoing EBITDA for the quarter of $115 million compared to $111 million last year. Higher earnings in Empress offset the effects of the lower Canadian dollar.
With respect to FX, the 13% reduction in the Canadian dollar affected EBITDA for both our Canadian business segments by $26 million quarter-over-quarter. Fortunately, about 2/3 of that number is naturally hedged on a net income basis, so the change in net income related to FX was only $6 million.
A number of you have expressed interest in how the current operating environment in Western Canada might affect our business risk going forward. So I want to take a moment and speak to the business model of that segment. First, 95% of our Western Canadian business, including gathering and processing, is fee-based with no direct commodity exposure or volume risk on existing contracts. While the Canadian pipeline model is similar to the model used in the U.S., it's important to remember that the Western Canadian G&P structure is different from the more commodity-sensitive model that largely exist across the U.S., GNP business.
Second, as you're aware, we implemented a risk management program at our Empress processing facility to reduce cash flow volume. At our February Analyst Day, we said that we expect at Empress to generate approximately $30 million of cash this year, and we're on track to exceed that forecast for 2015 given the hedges we put in place.
Looking forward to 2016, we've hedged about half of our targeted sales levels at positive margins, and we will continue to opportunistically layer in hedges to see year progresses.
It's also important to note that nearly all of our Empress propane and butane sales contracts and our hedging program are linked to Conway and Mont Belvieu pricing, not Edmonton.
Moving on to DCP. Our 50% share of DCP's ongoing EBITDA was a negative $27 million in the quarter compared with $54[ph] million last year. As expected, the decrease is primarily due to significantly lower commodity prices, which are down about 50% from last year's levels. These decreases were partially offset by increased earnings growth or increased earnings from asset growth, improved operating efficiencies and savings from other strategic initiatives.
While we all love to see stronger commodity prices and positive earnings at DCP, I would remind you of the counterintuitively effect DCP's lower earnings have on Spectra Energy's cash flows. Since distributions from DCP can't drop below 0, it's negative earnings benefit our DCF by ultimately lowering our cash taxes. So overall, Spectra Energy's ongoing EBITDA was up quarter-over-quarter despite both lower commodity prices and lower Canadian currency. And again the result of SEP reflect its significant organic growth, strong fee-based earnings and virtually no commodity or volume exposure.
Importantly, these results exceeded our budget expectations for the 2015 quarter.
Let's take a look at our DCF's scheduled beginning with SEP as shown on Slide 5. SEP's standalone distributable cash flow for the quarter was $321 million, $82 million more than the same quarter last year with distribution coverage of 1.3x. This higher DCF was directly attributable to the higher EBITDA I just described.
For the full year, we expect SEP's coverage to be at least 1.1x consistent with our 2015 forecast.
SEP general partner and the limited partner distributions still Spectra Energy for the quarter of $56 million and $145 million, respectively. And earlier this morning, SEP announced its 31st consecutive quarterly distribution increase of $0.0125 per unit. We continue to see strong interest in our ATM program at SEP. To this point in the year, SEP has raised almost $350 million through this vehicle.
Given the attractiveness of SEP's investor value proposition and the lack of commodity and volume exposure, we expect continued utilization at the ATM program throughout the year and can further expand the program if needed.
Let's turn now to Spectra Energy's distributable cash flow as shown on Slide 6. At Spectra Energy, distributable cash flow is $274 million for the quarter in line with last year. Coverage is 1.1x and DCF per share was $0.41. Year-to-date, we're at 1.7x coverage and by the end of the year, we expect coverage to be at least 1.2x, consistent with the forecast we provided at the beginning of the year.
Total available liquidity across the entire Spectra Energy enterprise was $3.5 billion as of June 30. So while we still have a little less than half a year to go, we're feeling very good about how the business is continuing to perform. We're ahead of where we thought we'd be at this point in time in terms of EBITDA and DCF despite the current environment.
We're very pleased with our performance today and expect to continue to deliver on the commitments we made for the balance of the year.
So with that, let me turn things over to Greg to talk about our growth opportunities and the progress we're making on our Drive to 35.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Pat, and good morning everybody. As you just heard, the results we delivered this quarter underscore the stability of our overall earnings and cash-generation capabilities. I think that stability comes from a well-positioned, high perfor
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Pat, and good morning everybody. As you just heard, the results we delivered this quarter underscore the stability of our overall earnings and cash-generation capabilities. I think that stability comes from a well-positioned, high performing portfolio of assets that allows us to generate value creating DCF regardless of commodity or market fluctuations. And it also reinforces our confidence and our ability to deliver ongoing annual dividend growth of $0.14 per share while maintaining coverage at/or above 1. Pat mentioned that we realized strong results for the quarter at both Spectra Energy and SEP. That significant and worth repeating, we believe the strength of our businesses and financial structure important differentiators allowing us to deliver consistent and dependable growth.
With everything that's occurring in the energy space, I want to take a minute to share our priorities for driving growth and increasing shareholder returns for both Spectra Energy and SEP investors. It goes without saying that safe, reliable operations are our assets is a big element of Spectra Energy success, and so we are steadfastly focused on day-to-day operations. That focus ensures that our customers' requirements are met in a safe and responsible manner. And my confidence on our operating team's ability gives me more time to concentrate on 4 other major areas. First, ensuring that we successfully execute on the secured project backlog that we already have and that we do so on time and on budget. Our execution advantage really does differentiate us, especially when you consider that most projects take several years to come into service given the current regulatory process. As you can imagine, this is no small undertaking, but we continue to deliver. This year, we've already put $600 million[ph] of expansion capital into service and this amount will grow to more than $2 billion by year end.
Second, I'm focused on securing contracts for projects that are in development. While our track record was just for successful and signing of the majority of projects we pursue, it's not possible to secure all of them. With that said, we continue to expect that we will secure contracts of at least another $20 billion of attractive returns by the end of the decade. To date, this year alone, we've moved more than $1 billion of projects in the execution and we expect to add to that by year end.
Third, with our partner, Phillip 66, we continue to focus on the appropriate structure of DCP to ensure that DCP and DPM are set up in a manner that provides the best opportunity for owners to realize their value. As we said before, we expect this matter will be resolved in the October timeframe as we work our way through the process, our objective remains as restructuring outcomes that allows DCP's enterprise to retain and grow its #1 position in NGL production and gas processing. It positions DCP to efficiently to finance that growth.
Lastly, I'm watching for industry consolidation opportunities that fit our portfolio strategically and add value to our shareholders. Our current Drive to 35 backlog does not contemplate any M&A activity. But as we've mentioned before, we're constantly looking at opportunities to complement our business portfolio and profile and advance our value creation objectives.
So with that, let me now turn to our projects and execution. As you've heard Pat mentioned, Spectra Energy and SEP's second quarter results benefited from new assets we successfully put in the ground last year. But we have also had 2 projects that moved into service since our last earnings call totaling about $600 million, so let me begin with those.
At U.S. Transmission, the Union Gas to Gas City project, service well ahead of its original November 1 in-service date, and DCP placed the Lucerne II processing plant in the DJ Basin into service since our last call along with several smaller gathering projects. We also have about $1.6 billion in projects that are nearing completion and are on track to go into service later this year. Our OPEN Project will bring incremental Marcellus and Utica supply to Southern markets beginning in November, not sooner; our 2015 Dawn-Parkway project is scheduled to go into service at Union Gas during the fourth quarter; DCP's on the final stages of starting up its CO2 processing plant in the Permian; and another Liquids segment, the Red Lake lateral to expand the rich Sand Hills to access growing Permian production will go fully into service once the CO2 comps online. Placing projects into service on time or even ahead of schedule is an example of how we've built our track record of delivering on our execution promises, an advantage for both customers and, of course, investors.
We've got a full complement of great projects and execution, which are detailed on this slide. I'll start by highlighting 3 new projects that we recently moved into execution. You recall that during last quarter, we mentioned OPEN season that were underway for projects that we would further critic Marcellus and Utica supply to demand markets. Since then, we moved our 11 on extension project in execution. We've secured commercial commitments for the project and are proceeding with the FERC approval process, an anticipated 2017 in-service date.
We also moved the High Pine project in the execution. High Pine is another project in Western Canada that will further expand the BC Pipeline. You'll recall that we announced the binding OPEN season for this project during our last earnings call, and we were able to quickly execute our commercial agreement to move the project forward. This $325 million project with have a late 2016 in-service date.
Another project we moved into execution this past quarter is the 2017 Dawn-Parkway project at Union Gas. Commercial contracts underpinning the $620 million project have been executed, application has been filed for approval with Ontario Energy Board. Other projects in execution are also proceeding well and are on track to meet their respective in-service dates. All of these projects underpinned by executed customer agreements that are unaffected by commodity market conditions. In fact you'll note that about 75% of our extension CapEx is driven by natural gas demand pull projects rather than supply-push.
During the quarter, both the AIM and 2016 Dawn-Parkway projects began construction and are on track to be in-service in the second half of 2016.
NEXUS is on track for its fourth quarter 2017 in-service date. We completed a major milestone and a regulatory process for this project by submitting our FERC resource reports in June and we anticipate filing a form of FERC application later this year.
Our execution efforts also continue on 2 projects in Western Canada to expand our BC Pipeline, the Jackfish Lake and REM projects. We expect both of these pipe and expansions to go into service during 2017. As you know, LNG projects on the West Coast of Canada and the U.S. have been delayed given current market dynamics, however, producers don't need to move natural gas. So this LNG deferment has led to these new opportunities for us in our Western Canadian pipeline, totaling about $1 billion already this year.
The pipeline expansion opportunities we're seeing in British Columbia underscore the benefit of having an expensive and strategic existing footprint in our region. At a time when the Montney region producers are looking for the lowest cost option to move their product quickly to the Pacific Northwest or Eastern Canada or Alberta markets, having a steel in the ground already is clearly a competitive advantage for us.
So wrapping up the review of projects in execution, we will have more than $2 billion of projects into service by year end, creating additional earnings and cash flow for 2016 and beyond. We are making great progress on all of our projects and execution, and we continue to further expand our execution backlog by adding about $1 billion of projects over justice last quarter.
You've seen on our impressive slate of projects in-service and execution projects, projects that will deliver the earnings and cash flow we laid out  to you in our 3-year plan for you in January and February. In addition to our backlog of projects and execution, we have a healthy portfolio of opportunities in development that will lead to continued growth and we're working diligently to move those projects forward.
Let me take a look at some of our projects that are in development. Access Northeast underdevelopment with Eversource and National Grid, continues to advance quite nicely. Unlike other projects in the region, which are intended to serve gas LDCs in England, Access Northeast will serve the electric power market. Project customers, including Eversource, National Grid and Central Maine Power, serve more than 80% of the 6.5 million electric customers in the region. The project will expand the Algonquin and Maritime systems utilizing their existing footprints. We expect the customers to field agreements with their respective PUC soon and anticipate moving Access Northeast and execution later this year or early 2016 once state regulatory approvals have been received by our customers.
An interesting note for you, we've already seen a record summertime demand from power generators on our existing Algonquin and Texas Eastern lines of this year, with new #1 delivery days of more than 800 million cubic feet a day on each of these lines and daily average deliveries to power generators of 21% over '14 on Algonquin and up 33% over 2014 on the East End markets on [indiscernible].
Also underdevelopment are 2 Marcellus and Utica expansion projects, the Greater Philadelphia Expansion and Marcellus market projects, which received positive responses to OPEN seasons during the quarter and discussions with potential customers are underway.
Moving to Western Canada, we kicked off another binding OPEN season in late July to further expand the north section of the BC Pipeline and we expect the results from that this fall. As I mentioned earlier, we're extremely pleased with the level of producer interest we're seeing for our BC Pipeline and we are exploring ways to further serve our producers in the Montney region.
Customer interest also remain strong in our larger scale crude oil projects in development. While we continue to expect a late in-the-decade timeframe to secure commitments to advance these projects, in the interim, we'll seek smaller scale optimization project similar to the $135 million Express Enhancement project currently in execution.
To summarize, we made significant progress during the quarter on our Drive to 35. In fact, we're more than halfway to our goal with $8.2 billion in service now and $9.6 billion in execution as I speak. We continue to advance our projects in execution and development to generate incremental cash flow and, of course, shareholder value.
As you've heard today, Spectra Energy delivered solid results for the quarter. We're disappointed, of course, that our stock price isn't reflecting the strong performance of our businesses, we are not alone. The energy sector is being painted with a far too broad brush and suffering the consequences of perceptions energy cash flows are correlated to commodity prices. That's just not the case, of course, and certainly not the case or Spectra Energy an SEP. The current environment allows investors to differentiate between investment options. So let me take a minute to remind you why Spectra Energy and SEP are best-in-class investment opportunities.
We understand what investors are looking for and Spectra Energy and SEP offer all those attributes. Specifically, we know that investors prefer strong portfolios. Our unrivaled footprint connects all the major North American supply basins with growing demand markets. It could not replicate our geographic positioning, nor reach today. Our healthy mix of businesses are structured to minimize the effect of multiple and varied market cycles.
Next we know that stable reliable cash flows are important for investors as well. As we told you back in February, 99% of Spectra Energy's EBITDA for the 2015 to 2017 period will come from our fee-based business, and our DCF forecast is virtually unexposed to incremental commodity downside. And SEP is fairly unique in the MLP space, as 95% of U.S. Transmission revenues, the largest component of SEP and Spectra Energy for that matter, is reservation based with no commodity, nor volume exposure. The average remaining contract term within our gas pipeline business is about 9 years, and the Express crude pipeline has an average contract term of 10 years, thanks to the contract restructuring we've done since acquiring this system in 2013.
Investors see companies with robust growth profile and again we're making great progress on our Drive to 35. By 2020, we'll grow our EBITDA by about $1 billion and approximately $800 million at Spectra Energy and SEP, respectively. The projects that we have in execution are moved into service and begin generating cash. And with the ongoing growth and the demand for natural gas and natural gas infrastructure, we have tremendous confidence in realizing our projects in development.
Healthy financials are also important and we have the financial flexibility to efficiently fund our growth projects and pursuing new opportunities. We have 2 solid currencies, strong investment grade balance sheet and disciplined financial management. Investors look for strong track record and proven performance and you've heard me talk about our execution advantage, unlike another feature that sets us apart. Since 2007, we've delivered more than 70 projects into service for capital expansion investment of about $9 billion, a record that speaks to our level of about ability and achievement.
Lastly and most importantly, investors want attractive returns. Spectra Energy has done that in the past 5 years, our annual dividend per share has grown from $1 to $1.48, and we're committed to continuing to grow Spectra Energy's dividend by at least $0.14 per share through 2017.
Similarly, SEP has delivered 31 consecutive quarters of distribution growth and we're committed to continuing that track record with an 8% to 9% annual growth rate through 2017.
So those are the attributes that differentiate Spectra Energy and SEP from other energy companies, and why we believe so strongly that both entities offer a best-in-class investment opportunity today.
With that, let me turn things over to Julie to take your questions on the quarter.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So some questions on SEP and the strength we're seeing there. You guys talked about in the release how the increasing quarter results were mainly due to 3 projects. The TEAM projects were put on September and November of last year, I think. So we've alrea
componenttext: So some questions on SEP and the strength we're seeing there. You guys talked about in the release how the increasing quarter results were mainly due to 3 projects. The TEAM projects were put on September and November of last year, I think. So we've already seen 1 or 2 full quarters from these assets, yet the beats in earlier quarters were nothing like they are today. So did the reservation team for these assets not all of come on, on day 1? Or are they are ramping up through the year? Any color on how we should think about that assets in maybe your other pipeline projects that are supposed to come online future would be helpful.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. You're right, there is some ramp up, so TEAM 14, TEAM South, the Kingsport project as well, didn't have a quick start up until ramp up and revenues until the end of the year. And I think a little bit better results on the New Jersey-New York project
componenttext: Sure. You're right, there is some ramp up, so TEAM 14, TEAM South, the Kingsport project as well, didn't have a quick start up until ramp up and revenues until the end of the year. And I think a little bit better results on the New Jersey-New York project as well than we expected. I think, through the rest of the year, call it $5 million maybe $10 million on the projects that we brought in early will be helpful, Christine, for the rest of the year as well.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of going off that, when we look at your SEP guidance, even if we were to keep EBITDA that from second quarter and third quarter and fourth quarter, you guys would still come in $80 million over guided. Given you still have so
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of going off that, when we look at your SEP guidance, even if we were to keep EBITDA that from second quarter and third quarter and fourth quarter, you guys would still come in $80 million over guided. Given you still have some projects coming online at the remainder of this year and we actually still have a winter to go through, would it be fair to say that your guidance is very conservative? Or am I missing something that may provide some offsets in the second half of this year?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, Christine, we don't change -- we come out with our numbers at the start of the year. I think, historically, if you look at the last few years that we've been doing DCF, we've typically under promised and over delivered. But you still do
componenttext: Well, as you know, Christine, we don't change -- we come out with our numbers at the start of the year. I think, historically, if you look at the last few years that we've been doing DCF, we've typically under promised and over delivered. But you still do have 2 quarters to go. And, of course, it wouldn't have affected first SEP that much in the first half of the year, the good strong winter versus have put in terms of additional revenues. So I'm not changing in the forecast, but I think history would say, we do try to under promise and over deliver.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given most of this, most of your cash flow is fee-based than take or pay, how should we think about a distribution increase above guidance or holding it may be fund some of your projects?
componenttext: Given most of this, most of your cash flow is fee-based than take or pay, how should we think about a distribution increase above guidance or holding it may be fund some of your projects?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's the balance, it's interesting because, I know, historically, and I've chatted about this, some people may have faster growth than us. But I think our kind of 8% to 10% outlook on distribution growth and, frankly, on dividend growth in
componenttext: Yes. I think that's the balance, it's interesting because, I know, historically, and I've chatted about this, some people may have faster growth than us. But I think our kind of 8% to 10% outlook on distribution growth and, frankly, on dividend growth in that range is the way to think about it. And I think, you see companies actually large dividend growth and distribution growth has actually moved up, you're seeing actually other companies come down to a number more in line with ours. So we look at dividend policy and distribution policy on a regular basis, but really make decision on annual basis towards the end of the year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pat. I think 1 thing you know is that you can't levelize things like maintenance CapEx during the year. So, for example, we've been averaging about 60% to 70% of our maintenance CapEx in the third and fourth quarters. So we're not changing our out
componenttext: This is Pat. I think 1 thing you know is that you can't levelize things like maintenance CapEx during the year. So, for example, we've been averaging about 60% to 70% of our maintenance CapEx in the third and fourth quarters. So we're not changing our outlook for maintenance, but we're just saying, remember, that there's a ramping up in the last half of the year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just in the Western Canadian segment, obviously, the producers out there exposed to the Edmonton propane prices must be struggling with net backs. I've seen data that indicated that the frac spread in Canada is actually not that much
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in the Western Canadian segment, obviously, the producers out there exposed to the Edmonton propane prices must be struggling with net backs. I've seen data that indicated that the frac spread in Canada is actually not that much different from the U.S. due to lower prices and natural gasoline prices that are higher in Canada, which surprised me a bit. Is that right? And as we think. . .

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I can say, I think, that's fair comment. I would say, you don't have this liquid market out there, A.  B, you got affected propane prices some infrastructure is used in our coach and changes. I guess, point I would make is that remember them the Emp
componenttext: Well, I can say, I think, that's fair comment. I would say, you don't have this liquid market out there, A.  B, you got affected propane prices some infrastructure is used in our coach and changes. I guess, point I would make is that remember them the Empress business is very much a Conway business. So when that -- at least with respect to our business, wouldn't focus too much on Edmonton as opposed to what's going from a Conway perspective.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I was more thinking about the outlook for GNP. What that would do -- what that's going to the rig activity in Western Canada and reaction to the prices? And also if you've heard about any solution that are being talked about for propane in the regio
componenttext: Well, I was more thinking about the outlook for GNP. What that would do -- what that's going to the rig activity in Western Canada and reaction to the prices? And also if you've heard about any solution that are being talked about for propane in the region, I've heard of some potential LPG exports in Western Canada or off the coast of Washington, do you think either of these could happen or too much regulatory red tape?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, I don't think it's regulatory red tape too much. I actually thinks, it's volume, remember, Western Canada produces about as much liquids as the entire industry as DCP would produce. So you need a lot of volume and at depressed NGL prices, I thin
componenttext: Actually, I don't think it's regulatory red tape too much. I actually thinks, it's volume, remember, Western Canada produces about as much liquids as the entire industry as DCP would produce. So you need a lot of volume and at depressed NGL prices, I think it's kind of tough from that perspective. That being said, I think June has the highest production at Western Canada in a very long time, I think, 13 or 14 Bcf. And while you're right, you're asking rig counts come off, you are still seeing a lot of gas being produced. And I think you see that affect hitting our pipeline business, which is as you know is a very long-term fee-based contract perspective. And I'm not sure many people would have predicted the Spectra Energy would added $1 billion in pipeline projects this year into our backlog at the Western Canada. And I think that you're going to have ebb and flows between GNP and from pipelines, but investors in the E&P business are going to be happy that the producers how pipelines that can take gas down to the Pacific Northwest and Alberta. So a lot of solutions being worked on, but I don't see huge NGL solution in the near term in Western Canada.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Last question for me, can you remind us how exactly the fee-based GNP model works in Western Canada? It's fee-based, but is there exposure to volumes? Or is there some sort of demand payment that also needs to get paid, as the contracts for a
componenttext: Okay, great. Last question for me, can you remind us how exactly the fee-based GNP model works in Western Canada? It's fee-based, but is there exposure to volumes? Or is there some sort of demand payment that also needs to get paid, as the contracts for a certain number of years so is there a recontracting risk, some detail about that would be helpful.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. You should think about it very much like negotiated pipeline rights in the United States. So we signed up contracts, 4 processing plants, long-term contracts and like the Dawson project that we put in place a couple of years was a 20-year contract w
componenttext: Sure. You should think about it very much like negotiated pipeline rights in the United States. So we signed up contracts, 4 processing plants, long-term contracts and like the Dawson project that we put in place a couple of years was a 20-year contract with a set fee that it's not volume risk, in other words, unlike you often see GNP in the United States not volume risk. Now at the end of contract life, just like on a pipeline in the United States or Canada, you are exposed to recontacting. So that's obviously, something you're always looking at. But I think, our average contract life would be 3 to 5 years for the overall portfolio. As I said projects like Dawson, more like 20 years. So think of it that much more like a negotiated rate pipeline as opposed to just cost of service.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Darren Horowitz with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Darren Horowitz with Raymond James.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, a couple of quick questions for you. The first on the 2 Appalachian expansion projects that you discussed. Just given the recent shift in basin dynamics and not only being imbalanced between supply growth and demand, but a lot of the pipe options ou
componenttext: Greg, a couple of quick questions for you. The first on the 2 Appalachian expansion projects that you discussed. Just given the recent shift in basin dynamics and not only being imbalanced between supply growth and demand, but a lot of the pipe options out of the region and the impact on regional pricing differentials may be shifting economics or at least net back incentives. I'm just wondering if anything has changed from customers on processing your perspective, maybe a better way to ask the question is, if you could kind of quantify or give us some color on what positive response to the OPEN season means. And then secondly, the 1 project that wasn't discuss was that Texas-Eastern Lebanon expansion project, and I was just wondering in terms of incremental CapEx to scale that project up, if there could be any opportunity for that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, ready questions and in [indiscernible] is in the room as well. But really, I would say, customers have the same message, get my product to a demand market, very simple. Or get me partial on the trail. And so you've seen us a put a variety o
componenttext: Well, I think, ready questions and in [indiscernible] is in the room as well. But really, I would say, customers have the same message, get my product to a demand market, very simple. Or get me partial on the trail. And so you've seen us a put a variety of idea projects that not only might take gas, molecules a long distance, but actually to the next closest liquid point. So you will see the projects ebb and flow in terms of their size. I don't think there's anything, I mean, restricting customers from signing up. Sure, E&P customers are very focused on their cap spend and were they think commodity prices will go. But I think, the Lebanon project, as you'll see on 1 of the slides that we put out of the $9 billion, we did put it into execution this quarter, Darren. And I would say, it's lumped in with the Access South and there in Adair Southwest expansion because they really are, in many respects, for some different customers, achieving similar type goals. So even in the way we're going to FERC and have those approved, we have lumped in as 1 project. So you can continue to see projects morph. I think the underlying facet that's really critical and a real advantage for Spectra, we already have assets in the ground and we're going to -- and I hear a lot of discussion about reversing flows and stuff, please, guys, we've been doing that for a number of years now. So I know other folks are starting to think and get to that. That's not novel for Spectra and our customers so I think that's why you're seeing some of the results that you are seeing. Phil, I don't know if you want to add to that?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no. I think, we're still seeing some pretty good interest in both the Marcellus and Utica regions from producers, it's a little bit longer lead time than perhaps it was couple of years ago. But we have a lot of faith in these 2 projects, both Marcellu
componenttext: No, no. I think, we're still seeing some pretty good interest in both the Marcellus and Utica regions from producers, it's a little bit longer lead time than perhaps it was couple of years ago. But we have a lot of faith in these 2 projects, both Marcellus and the Utica market come to fruition at some point in the not too distant future.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: I think the gating issue, as well, look, to build anything these days is expensive. And I think as always, in any good business relationship, there's negotiation back-and-back and forth, and you've got to find the common ground where it makes economic sense for both parties.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that makes sense. Last question for me is just on Access Northeast and I realized, it's still under development and a little bit of a moving target. But when you think about the ultimate scale and scope of that $3 billion project and then you
componenttext: Yes, I think that makes sense. Last question for me is just on Access Northeast and I realized, it's still under development and a little bit of a moving target. But when you think about the ultimate scale and scope of that $3 billion project and then you reconcile that with a lot of the proposed consolidation in the area and maybe again, a bit of a shift in terms of scale and scope of some competitors pipes, to your point and I actually agree with you, obviously, following Algonquin and [indiscernible], gives you just from a footprint perspective and a right of way perspective, a bit of an advance but a little bit of a timing shift to your, obviously, for regulatory perspective and certainly, that's not getting easier. But I'm wondering, just with some of the different proposed consolidation, dynamics, economies of scale and what could come out of that area over the next possibly 12 to 18 months, how could that impact Access Northeast either at ultimate scale scope from a timing perspective or from a further growth opportunity standpoint?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I don't think that will change the time. I mean, as I noted, just volume increase we're seeing in terms of our deliveries to generators, I think -- and remember, this summer, the challenge is really in the winter and we're already seeing 20%,
componenttext: Yes. Again, I don't think that will change the time. I mean, as I noted, just volume increase we're seeing in terms of our deliveries to generators, I think -- and remember, this summer, the challenge is really in the winter and we're already seeing 20%, 30% increase out there. I don't think there's that time they want to keep the lights on. And I think the Eversources, the National Grids to the world, which represent, what's, $5.5 million of 6.5 million customers out there, Bill, I think they recognize. So I don't see changes there. I would also say that doesn't take away form any other projects that are also needed out there. Remember, our AIM, our Atlantic Bridge projects are about LDCs, that's already in execution, well in execution. The other projects about -- the Access Northeast is about electric. Other folks major projects being pitched are LDC-related projects. So I think the dynamics don't allow for changes. I think, the dynamics that we're seeing more like additional projects that will be coming forth over the following year. So if you think we've got 16, 17, 18 projects coming into service, if you look at gas demand in North America going from 75 Bcf a day to the 100 Bcf, 110 Bcf a day in the next 10 years, despite what any brilliant policy may be coming out of government officials, that will happen. And those what's going to happen in the Northeast and that's advantage pipeline, that's got to happen unless people are willing to let lights go out, get cold. At this time, you're going to put a hot stick in the Northeast.

componenttext: Brandon, it's Bill Yardley. We're really interested in all 6 states, there's an overarching statement. I'd say that we've got pretty clear authority in 1 state, Rhode Island, and the other 4 states are going through some sort of process. We expect those processes to be very clear by years end. At the same time, we will be preparing the contracts for the 7 utilities that we have under negotiating with, we're give to submit those with each respective state. And then, of course, entering the prefiling process and then looking for those state approvals, as Greg mentioned, probably next year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. That's appreciated. Sticking with the Northeast, Uniontown to Gas City online, 3 months early. I guess, the question, is what was the driver for that accelerated pace? And is there any reads to the OPEN Project? Or anything else that's happeni
componenttext: Okay, good. That's appreciated. Sticking with the Northeast, Uniontown to Gas City online, 3 months early. I guess, the question, is what was the driver for that accelerated pace? And is there any reads to the OPEN Project? Or anything else that's happening in the Northeast?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, depending on where you're working obviously, and I'll give our project execution team full credit. I think this is an advantage we have, very keen on local game as opposed to state or national games in terms of getting stuff approved and th
componenttext: Well, I think, depending on where you're working obviously, and I'll give our project execution team full credit. I think this is an advantage we have, very keen on local game as opposed to state or national games in terms of getting stuff approved and the delivery was there. On OPEN, obviously, our time frame is still the 1st of November, and I'm hopeful that we'll be able to do that early as well. Obviously, everyday, we can get the pipe in earlier that has benefits from a safety perspective, from an operational perspective and, obviously, from an economic perspective in many cases, not always the contracts ramp up early. But I will tell you, the customers that have got the projects, they like it coming in early back to the point I was making that anytime we can get their project like away from supplier, to do the demand area, they'll take it all day long. So we're pushing as hard as we can. We obviously, have a very systematic approach to doing projects, this is not a new area for us. We're talking half a century of building stuff there and we're getting advantage of that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And just real quick, bigger picture question. Montney customers, you mentioned, I think, Greg, in your prepared comments that there's an interest in finding an outlet that's not LNG for obvious reasons. The question is, is that a permanent sol
componenttext: Okay, good. And just real quick, bigger picture question. Montney customers, you mentioned, I think, Greg, in your prepared comments that there's an interest in finding an outlet that's not LNG for obvious reasons. The question is, is that a permanent solution, bringing gas to the U.S. instead of LNG? Or is this just a temporary outlet from the Montney customer perspective?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll no. What I would say is a bit of both obviously, we've signed with long-term contracts, cost of service base. I think, it's a combination of both a longer-term solution. I will be surprised to see any LNG in the West Coast of North America definitel
componenttext: We'll no. What I would say is a bit of both obviously, we've signed with long-term contracts, cost of service base. I think, it's a combination of both a longer-term solution. I will be surprised to see any LNG in the West Coast of North America definitely not going to happen before 2020 at this point in time, even if you saw approvals happen instantly just the amount of work that gets done. Whether you think a 6- to 10-year solution is a long-term or not, but I think you're talking about of while before those projects kick in. And remember, as demand grows across North America, the Pacific Northwest, Alberta production is often -- has been declining, so Western Canada is not a single market. And you're still seeing activity going on from demand perspective in the oil sands of which much of the fuel they need to use is natural gas. So yes, I mean, there's no doubt the opportunity has been created by LNG deferment. But the amount of grass we're talking about is nowhere near the amount of gas that would be needed for LNG. So one is not going to replace the other, the LNG would just be incremental to that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had a question, if Congress passes the 2-year extension of bonus depreciation, could you guys talk a little bit about how that would impact Spectra distributable cash flow?
componenttext: Just had a question, if Congress passes the 2-year extension of bonus depreciation, could you guys talk a little bit about how that would impact Spectra distributable cash flow?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There sure seems to be a very growing momentum in Congress for at least 1, and it seems increasingly a 2-year extension of bonus depreciation. So as you may recall, we wind out in our 3-year forecast, we see about $300 million in cash taxes in '16 an
componenttext: Yes. There sure seems to be a very growing momentum in Congress for at least 1, and it seems increasingly a 2-year extension of bonus depreciation. So as you may recall, we wind out in our 3-year forecast, we see about $300 million in cash taxes in '16 and '17. You could take about $0.25 billion of that cash taxes in '16 and '17. So rough numbers that makes your coverage 20% above your dividend, so call it 1.2 range. So it's obviously, out of everything folks are looking at, that's probably the most impactful change and probably the one that's on a pretty good momentum. I don't have control over that, but I think the reality is that infrastructure builds in this country are critical and I think Congress on a bipartisan basis, obviously, recognizes that and sees the benefit that have been out there. Yes, we'll be watching that closely as we go through the rest of the year.

componenttext: Can you just talk about NEXUS a little bit? How much of the volume, I think you're looking for B and half there, how much the volume's contracted? headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we're about 70% contracted. As you know, a big element, an important element of that is the LDCs that are, I think, account for about 40% of the volumes. They're going through the regulatory processes, now those contracts have been filed fo
componenttext: Well, I think, we're about 70% contracted. As you know, a big element, an important element of that is the LDCs that are, I think, account for about 40% of the volumes. They're going through the regulatory processes, now those contracts have been filed for approval. I think the project -- it's in that 8% to 10% range. Obviously, if we don't have the full volumes there on start up, it's going to be more on the low end of that range. And I think the volume's actually are about 1.2, Ted, in terms of what we're targeting in NEXUS, it could be up to a B and a half, but I think our base economics are 1.2. Remember, that's unlevered after-tax IRR.

So management teams has done very good job of managing the liquidities in place to take us to the end of the year and into that October timeframe -- well, within that October timeframe. So stay tuned, Ted, we continue to work on that and believe that given the partners relationship ongoing cooperation, we're going to get there.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd be a little bit careful. Obviously, there's a whole range of stuff, Ted, obviously, a lot of asset sales out there, private equity, all that kind of stuff. So it depends, I will say, from a selling perspective, we've been very pleased what we've
componenttext: Yes, I'd be a little bit careful. Obviously, there's a whole range of stuff, Ted, obviously, a lot of asset sales out there, private equity, all that kind of stuff. So it depends, I will say, from a selling perspective, we've been very pleased what we've seen, very healthy multiples on what we've sold out of DCP which were assets that weren't really key for us. So I'd say, maybe the best way to say is, look, the key is to expand the footprint where we can find synergies, and to the extent we can you tax synergies, which allowed other folks have already played that card, we have not. So we'll be looking at that. I mean, I guess my fundamental belief is obviously, as we've doubled the size of the company in the last 5 years, doubling the size in the next 5 years is critical. And could you leapfrog elements of that with some transactions that may come to floor. But obviously, it's a bit of a -- it's not something you can plan on, it's not in our 3-year plan, we don't need to have that happen to hit our targets. But there's probably some people under stress and we aren't.

componenttext: Well, no. But there are so many big players, I wouldn't, say a limit on size. I guess, my bottom line would be size is an important element longer term, but I wouldn't say, there's a limit on size. We've done everything, if you've looked at the history from call it $8 million, $10 million deals with West Coast, which was that's 10, 12 years ago to call it $1 billion on oil pipeline. So I'd say anywhere in the mix that most of pull forward. But I wouldn't -- size is not the determinant, it's far more the economic, strategic and footprint expansion that we're looking for.

componenttext: Okay. On an Access Northeast, I thought I remembered you guys targeting definitive agreements by June 30. headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kinder is not -- yes, the Kinder project is not a determinant on our project. We're fine with a customer agreement these years to get them approved by the PUC. That's the gating issue for us. I think it's fair to say, Becca, that historically, we wou
componenttext: Yes. Kinder is not -- yes, the Kinder project is not a determinant on our project. We're fine with a customer agreement these years to get them approved by the PUC. That's the gating issue for us. I think it's fair to say, Becca, that historically, we would have put a project of this nature already in execution. But because of the unique element of an electric distribution company, seeking approval for gas transmission capacity, which is not being done in that neck of the woods, that makes us a little bit more cautious. But I think even Kinder Morgan recent days that, in fact, it's not 1 of the other both projects are needed, and that's where we've been for quite some time as well.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Understand. And last on DCP, just wanted to clarify that your stand hasn't changed that you would not put equity into DCP and that you would not have reduction in your ownership stake, that you're not willing to do that.

componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I don't see a solution as us putting equity in Spectra Energy equity whether it changes our ownership, that's always something that I've put on the table historically. We like the business, the issue is one of value, Becca. And I think with any
componenttext: Well, yes, I don't see a solution as us putting equity in Spectra Energy equity whether it changes our ownership, that's always something that I've put on the table historically. We like the business, the issue is one of value, Becca. And I think with any of our assets with portfolio managers and so if the value is greater than not hold it, then hold it then we do the right thing from that perspective. Historically, we've never found that's been the case.

componenttext: A bit of both. The scope would decline a little bit from our perspective. So therefore, that brought down the size. Obviously, we wanted to build for our customers and the customers that signed up when we got the critical mass in terms of contracts, we said go. So originally we might have seen some more contracts on that. However, Elvira, when some of those customers could make up their mind, we said go because we wanted to deliver for the folks that we already had in hand.
