componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to the consolidation question, are you looking across -- would you look across hydrocarbons? That's number 1. And number 2, would you look at anything that would increase commodity price exposure at the SE level?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Look, I mean, I think we've been very clear -- well, first of all, let's remind everybody that if you look at our 3-year plan, our DCF has virtually no incremental exposure to commodity prices. And we think that's a real value differentiator. And I th
componenttext: No. Look, I mean, I think we've been very clear -- well, first of all, let's remind everybody that if you look at our 3-year plan, our DCF has virtually no incremental exposure to commodity prices. And we think that's a real value differentiator. And I think you'll see that in the quarter. So obviously, we would -- we're very focused on anything we do to be largely the vast majority fee-based, depending on asset that we might buy, if it had some small elements, which may not stand the portfolio from a long-term perspective of commodity, that's not going to stop me from looking at it. The issue is what you would do it from a long-term perspective. I'll give you a good example, it really isn't commodity, but sometimes you do think that maybe it's not the perfect fit but turn out to be quite well. When we bought West Coast, Union Gas, which is still in our portfolio and we have well in excess of a couple of billion dollars of expansion projects for utility we would expect on pipeline, that may not fit perfectly but it's a good generator. Meanwhile, other utilities that we held when we bought West Coast, we have sold those assets. I think none of that would stop the big prices and what we look out on the West Coast, which was really the pipeline operations that we liked in Canada. But the focus definitely from a fee-based perspective.

componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have definitely been asked and answered, but I was wondering if you could just do 2 little follow-up questions related to DCP, I realize you're not providing an update on the strategy at this stage right now. But you've been very reso
componenttext: Most of my questions have definitely been asked and answered, but I was wondering if you could just do 2 little follow-up questions related to DCP, I realize you're not providing an update on the strategy at this stage right now. But you've been very resolute in the past in saying that money goes one way. Has that changed at all just given how bad the NGL market has been? Or can we still continue to assume that as SE will not be injecting any capital into DCP?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, we've been clear that we don't plan to put SE equity into it. We have supported it in a variety of ways, historically, and today. So I don't want to split hair here, but as you know, over the next 3 years, we have forgone our right to take distri
componenttext: I think, we've been clear that we don't plan to put SE equity into it. We have supported it in a variety of ways, historically, and today. So I don't want to split hair here, but as you know, over the next 3 years, we have forgone our right to take distributions that are available for us to take. So I don't want to -- it would be hard to say that's not as bleeding cash, not taking cash, I guess, we could have it home and given it back, A. So I think we do put cash in from time to time, the point is SE equity in it. And B, we've also bought assets and that's worked out well. If they are fee-based, we own 1/3 of those NGL pipelines, which are really great assets. So I think I'd look at it that way. But yes, I would say that's no change in the position we have had historically.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. That's what I wanted to confirm and I realize it's splitting hairs there. But specifically, SE equity is not going in. And then the second question, Pat, you would sort of talked about the perverse tax benefit as a result, and so you basically
componenttext: Okay, cool. That's what I wanted to confirm and I realize it's splitting hairs there. But specifically, SE equity is not going in. And then the second question, Pat, you would sort of talked about the perverse tax benefit as a result, and so you basically the more DCP you lose effectively the better it is for you on a cash flow basis at least in the near term until you max out the tax benefit. But if there's any change in the Spectra's ownership of the GP, let's say, one of those solutions is somebody to inject capital and you find a partner and your ownership is diluted, let's say, down to 20% or 25%, would that change your ability to continue to have that tax benefit? Or you would still continue to have equity method accounting and it would still flow through?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. We still follow the equity method accounting. We pick up our share at any EBITDA loss and then that would generate current cash tax savings. So to your point, it would just be proportionately less than it otherwise would have been.
componenttext: It's the latter. We still follow the equity method accounting. We pick up our share at any EBITDA loss and then that would generate current cash tax savings. So to your point, it would just be proportionately less than it otherwise would have been.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angel, and good morning, everyone. My name is Julie Dill, the Chief Communications Officer for Spectra Energy. Thank you for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners' 2015 Second Quarter Results.With me
componenttext:
Thank you, Angel, and good morning, everyone. My name is Julie Dill, the Chief Communications Officer for Spectra Energy. Thank you for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners' 2015 Second Quarter Results.
With me today are Greg Ebel, President and CEO of both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners; and Pat Reddy, Chief Financial Officer both companies. Pat will discuss our results for the quarter and then Greg will update you on our growth opportunities and the progress we're making on our Drive to 35. And as always, we'll leave plenty of time for your questions.
Our safe harbor statement is contained within our presentation materials and available on our website. This disclaimer is important and integral to all our remarks, so I would ask that you refer to it as you review our materials. Also contained in our presentation materials are non-GAAP measures that we reconcile to the most directly comparable GAAP measures, and those reconciliations are also available on our website.
So with that, let me turn things over to Pat.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered very strong ongoing EBITDA for the quarter. But before I get into the details of those
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. 
As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered very strong ongoing EBITDA for the quarter. But before I get into the details of those results, I want to discuss some special items we recorded during the quarter as shown on Slide 3.
There were 3 special items which lowered reported EBITDA by $217 million or $0.20 per share. As you can see on this slide, only 1 of these items affected DCF by $11 million. The first item is $194 million pretax, noncash charge or $122 million after-tax, which represents our 50% share of a goodwill impairment at DCP. The second item also is associated with DCP and is a pretax, noncash charge of $12 million related to our share of a loss on the sale of an asset during the quarter. Lastly, Western Canada recorded a pretax special item of $11 million related to employee and overhead reductions. We expect there will be some incremental charges of less than $10 million related to these efforts that will be recorded in the third and fourth quarters.
Our ongoing EBITDA increased year-over-year, so let's turn to those results, which really tell the story of the strength and resilience of our business model. As noted, we delivered very strong second quarter results with ongoing EBITDA of $652 million at Spectra Energy and $456 million at Spectra Energy Partners. Given the current macro environment, it is significant that Spectra Energy's ongoing EBITDA increase 4% quarter-over-quarter. 
As we've consistently demonstrated year after year, our portfolio of asset is structured to moderate the effect of various business cycles and maximize the upside benefits. And with approximately 95% fee base earnings at U.S. Transmission that have no exposure to commodity price or volume fluctuations, SEP is a standout in the MLP space. 
So let's take a look at the drivers of our results by segment. I'll start with Spectra Energy Partners, whose EBITDA was up almost 30%. SEP is comprised of our U.S. Transmission and Liquids businesses and is shown on the upper right hand corner of Slide 4. U.S. Transmission delivered EBITDA of $396 million, up $76 million. That is almost 24% higher than the same quarter last year. Results for the 2015 quarter were driven primarily by increased earnings from expansion projects placed into service, specifically, TEAM 2014, TEAM South and the Kingsport project.
Our Liquids business reported second quarter EBITDA of $78 million compared with $51 million in 2014. The increase was primarily driven by higher volumes and tariff on the Express crude pipeline, as well as higher equity earnings from the increased volumes on the Sand Hills natural gas liquids pipeline. As you can see, SEP is performing very well and delivering results ahead of our expectations.
Moving to the table on the left-hand side of this slide, distribution reported second quarter EBITDA of $98 million compared to $112 million in 2014. The decrease quarter-over-quarter was due almost entirely to the decline in the value of the Canadian dollar, which was down 13% this quarter compared with 2014.
Western Canada recorded ongoing EBITDA for the quarter of $115 million compared to $111 million last year. Higher earnings in Empress offset the effects of the lower Canadian dollar.
With respect to FX, the 13% reduction in the Canadian dollar affected EBITDA for both our Canadian business segments by $26 million quarter-over-quarter. Fortunately, about 2/3 of that number is naturally hedged on a net income basis, so the change in net income related to FX was only $6 million.
Now, a number of you have expressed interest in how the current operating environment in Western Canada might affect our business risk going forward. So I want to take a moment and speak to the business model of that segment. 
First, 95% of our Western Canadian business, including gathering and processing, is fee-based with no direct commodity exposure or volume risk on existing contracts. While the Canadian pipeline model is similar to the model used in the U.S., it's important to remember that the Western Canadian G&P structure is different from the more commodity-sensitive model that largely exist across the U.S., GNP business.
Second, as you're aware, we implemented a risk management program at our Empress processing facility to reduce cash flow volume. At our February Analyst Day, we said that we expect that Empress to generate approximately $30 million of cash this year, and we're on track to exceed that forecast for 2015 given the hedges we put in place.
Looking forward to 2016, we've hedged about half of our targeted sales levels at positive margins, and we will continue to opportunistically layer in hedges to see year progresses. It's also important to note that nearly all of our Empress propane and butane sales contracts and our hedging program are linked to Conway and Mont Belvieu pricing, not Edmonton.
Moving on to DCP. Our 50% share of DCP's ongoing EBITDA was a negative $27 million in the quarter compared with $54 million last year. As expected, the decrease is primarily due to significantly lower commodity prices, which are down about 50% from last year's levels. These decreases were partially offset by increased earnings growth or increased earnings from asset growth, improved operating efficiencies and savings from other strategic initiatives.
While we all love to see stronger commodity prices and positive earnings at DCP, I would remind you of the counterintuitively effect DCP's lower earnings have on Spectra Energy's cash flows. Since distributions from DCP can't drop below 0, it's negative earnings benefit our DCF by ultimately lowering our cash taxes. 
So overall, Spectra Energy's ongoing EBITDA was up quarter-over-quarter despite both lower commodity prices and the lower Canadian currency. And again the results at SEP reflect its significant organic growth, strong fee-based earnings and virtually no commodity or volume exposure.
Importantly, these results exceeded our budget expectations for the 2015 quarter. Let's take a look at our DCF's scheduled beginning with SEP as shown on Slide 5. SEP's standalone distributable cash flow for the quarter was $321 million, $82 million more than the same quarter last year with distribution coverage of 1.3x. This higher DCF was directly attributable to the higher EBITDA I just described. For the full year, we expect SEP's coverage to be at least 1.1x consistent with our 2015 forecast.
SEP paid general partner and limited partner distributions to Spectra Energy for the quarter of $56 million and $145 million, respectively. And earlier this morning, SEP announced its 31st consecutive quarterly distribution increase of $0.0125 per unit. We continue to see strong interest in our ATM program at SEP. To this point in the year, SEP has raised almost $350 million through this vehicle. Given the attractiveness of SEP's investor value proposition and the lack of commodity and volume exposure, we expect continued utilization at the ATM program throughout the year and can further expand the program if needed.
Let's turn now to Spectra Energy's distributable cash flow as shown on Slide 6. At Spectra Energy, distributable cash flow is $274 million for the quarter in line with last year. Coverage is 1.1x and DCF per share was $0.41. Year-to-date, we're at 1.7x coverage and by the end of the year, we expect coverage to be at least 1.2x, consistent with the forecast we provided at the beginning of the year.
Total available liquidity across the entire Spectra Energy enterprise was $3.5 billion as of June 30. So while we still have a little less than half a year to go, we're feeling very good about how the business has continued to perform. We're ahead of where we thought we'd be at this point in time in terms of EBITDA and DCF despite the current environment. We're very pleased with our performance today and expect to continue to deliver on the commitments we made for the balance of the year.
So with that, let me turn things over to Greg to talk about our growth opportunities and the progress we're making on our Drive to 35.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Pat, and good morning everybody. As you just heard, the results we delivered this quarter underscore the stability of our overall earnings and cash-generation capabilities. I think that stability comes from a well-positioned, high-perf
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Pat, and good morning everybody. 
As you just heard, the results we delivered this quarter underscore the stability of our overall earnings and cash-generation capabilities. I think that stability comes from a well-positioned, high-performing portfolio of assets that allows us to generate value creating DCF regardless of commodity or market fluctuations. It also reinforces our confidence and our ability to deliver ongoing annual dividend growth of $0.14 per share while maintaining coverage at/or above 1. Pat mentioned that we realized strong results for the quarter at both Spectra Energy and SEP, that's significant and worth repeating. We believe the strength of our businesses and financial structure are important differentiators allowing us to deliver consistent and dependable growth.
With everything that's occurring in the energy space, I want to take a minute to share our priorities for driving growth and increasing shareholder returns for both Spectra Energy and SEP investors. It goes without saying that safe, reliable operations on our assets is a big element of Spectra Energy's success, and so we are steadfastly focused on day-to-day operations. That focus ensures that our customers' requirements are met in a safe and responsible manner. And my confidence on our operating team's abilities gives me more time to concentrate on 4 other major areas. 
First, ensuring that we successfully execute on the secured project backlog that we already have and that we do so on time and on budget. Our execution advantage really does differentiate us, especially when you consider that most projects take several years to come into service given the current regulatory process. As you can imagine, this is no small undertaking, but we continue to deliver. This year, we've already put $600 billion of expansion capital in the service and this amount will grow to more than $2 billion by year end.
Second, I'm focused on securing contracts for projects that are in development. While our track record would suggest we're successful on signing up the majority of projects we pursue, we know it's not possible to secure all of them. With that said, we continue to expect that we will secure contracts of at least another $20 billion at attractive returns by the end of the decade. To date, this year alone, we've moved more than $1 billion of projects in the execution and we expect to add to that in a meaningful way by year end.
Third, with our partner, Phillip 66, we continue to focus on the appropriate structure of DCP to ensure that DCP and DPM are set up in a manner that provides the best opportunity for the owners to realize their value. As we said before, we expect this matter will be resolved in the October timeframe as we work our way through the process, our ultimate objective remains ensuring that any structuring outcomes still allows DCP's enterprise to retain and grow its #1 position in NGL production and gas processing. That it positions DCP to efficiently finance that growth.
Lastly, I'm watching for industry consolidation opportunities that fit our portfolio strategically and add value to our shareholders. Our current Drive to 35 backlog does not contemplate any M&A activity. But as we've mentioned before, we're constantly looking at opportunities to complement our business portfolio and profile and advance our value of creation objectives.
So with that, let me now turn to our projects and execution. As you've heard Pat mentioned, Spectra Energy and SEP's second quarter results benefited from new assets we successfully put in the ground last year. But we have also had 2 projects that moved into service since our last earnings call totaling about $600 million, so let me begin with those.
At U.S. Transmission, the Union Gas -- the Uniontown Gas to Gas City project commence service well ahead of its original November 1 in-service date, and DCP placed the Lucerne II processing plant in the DJ Basin into service since our last call along with several smaller gathering projects. We also have about $1.6 billion in projects that are nearing completion and are on track to go into service later this year. 
Our OPEN Project will bring incremental Marcellus and Utica supply to Southern markets beginning in November, if not sooner. Our 2015 Dawn-Parkway project is scheduled to go into service at Union Gas during the fourth quarter. DCP's on the final stages of starting up its CO2 processing plant in the Permian. And at our Liquids segment, the Red Lake lateral to expand the reach of Sand Hills to access growing Permian production, will go fully into service once CO2 comes online. 
Placing projects into service on time or even ahead of schedule is an example of how we've built our track record of delivering on our execution promises, an advantage for both customers and, of course, investors. We've got a full complement of great projects and execution, which are detailed on this slide. I'll start by highlighting 3 new projects that we recently moved into execution. You recall that during last quarter, we mentioned OPEN seasons that were underway for projects that would further connect Marcellus and Utica supply to demand markets. Since then, we moved our 11 on extension project and execution. We've secured commercial commitments for the project and are proceeding with the FERC approval process and anticipated 2017 in-service date.
We also moved the High Pine project in the execution. High Pine is another project in Western Canada that will further expand the BC Pipeline. You'll recall that we announced the binding OPEN season for this project during our last earnings call, and we were able to quickly execute our commercial agreement to move the project forward. This $325 million project with have a late 2016 in-service date.
Another project we moved into execution this past quarter is the 2017 Dawn-Parkway project at Union Gas. Commercial contracts underpinning this $620 million project have been executed, facility's application has been filed for approval with the Ontario Energy Board. 
Other projects in execution are also proceeding well and are on track to meet their respective in-service dates. All of these projects are underpinned by executed customer agreements that are unaffected by commodity market conditions. In fact you'll note that about 75% of our expansion CapEx is driven by natural gas demand pull projects rather than supply-push.
During the quarter, both the AIM and 2016 Dawn-Parkway projects began construction and are on track to be in-service in the second half of 2016.  NEXUS is on track for its fourth quarter 2017 in-service date. We completed a major milestone and a regulatory process for this project by submitting our FERC resource reports in June and we anticipate filing a form of FERC application later this year.
Our execution efforts also continue on 2 projects in Western Canada to expand our BC Pipeline, the Jackfish Lake and RAM projects. We expect both of these pipeline expansions to go into service during 2017. As you know, LNG projects on the West Coast of Canada and the U.S. have been delayed given current market dynamics. However, producers don't need to move natural gas. So this LNG deferment has led to these new opportunities for us in our Western Canadian pipeline, totaling about $1 billion already this year.
The pipeline expansion opportunities we're seeing in British Columbia underscore the benefit of having an expensive and strategic existing footprint in our region. At a time when the Montney region producers are looking for the lowest cost option to move their product quickly to the Pacific Northwest or Eastern Canada or Alberta markets, having steel in the ground already is clearly a competitive advantage for us.
So wrapping up the review of projects in execution, we would have brought more than $2 billion of projects into service by year end, creating additional earnings and cash flow for 2016 and beyond. We're making great progress on all of our projects and execution, and we continue to further expand our execution backlog by adding about $1 billion of projects over just this last quarter.
You've seen our impressive slate of projects in-service and in execution, projects that would deliver the earnings in cash flow we laid in our our 3-year plan for you in January, February. In addition to our backlog of projects and execution, we have a healthy portfolio of opportunities in development that will lead to continued growth and we're working diligently to move those projects forward.
Let me take a look at some of our projects that are in development. Access Northeast underdevelopment with Eversource and National Grid, continues to advance quite nicely. Unlike other projects in the region, which are intended to serve gas LDCs in New England, Access Northeast will serve the electric power market. Project customers, including Eversource, National Grid and Central Maine Power, serve more than 80% of the 6.5 million electric customers in the region. The project will expand the Algonquin and Maritime systems utilizing their existing footprints. We expect the customers to file agreements with their respective PUC soon and we anticipate moving Access Northeast and the execution later this year or early 2016 once state regulatory approvals have been received by our customers.
An interesting note for you, we've already seen a record summertime demand from power generators on our existing Algonquin and Texas Eastern lines this year, with new #1 delivery days of more than 800 million cubic feet a day on each of these lines and daily average deliveries to power generators up 21% over '14 on Algonquin and up 33% over 2014 on the east end markets on 3 at TETCO. Also underdevelopment are 2 Marcellus and Utica expansion projects, the Greater Philadelphia Expansion and Marcellus to Market projects, which received positive responses to OPEN seasons during the quarter and discussions with potential customers are underway.
Moving to Western Canada, we kicked off another binding OPEN season in late July to further expand the T-North section of the BC Pipeline and we expect the results from that this fall. As I mentioned earlier, we're extremely pleased with the level of producer interest we're seeing for our BC Pipeline and we're exploring ways to further serve producers in the Montney region.
Customer interest also remains strong on our large scale crude oil projects in development. While we continue to expect a late in-the-decade timeframe to secure commitments to advance these projects, in the interim, we'll seek smaller scale optimization project similar to the $135 million Express Enhancement project currently in execution.
To summarize, we made significant progress during the quarter on our Drive to 35. In fact, we're more than halfway to our goal with $8.2 billion in service now and $9.6 billion in execution as I speak. We continue to advance our projects in execution and development to generate incremental cash flow and, of course, shareholder value.
As you've heard today, Spectra Energy delivered solid results for the quarter. We're disappointed, of course, that our stock price isn't reflecting the strong performance of our businesses. We're not alone. The energy sector is being painted with a far too broad brush and suffering the consequences of perceptions that all energy cash flows are correlated to commodity prices. That's just not the case, of course, and certainly not the case for Spectra Energy and SEP. The current environment allows investors to differentiate between investment options. So let me take a minute to remind you why Spectra Energy and SEP are best-in-class investment opportunities.
We understand what investors are looking for and Spectra Energy and SEP offer all those attributes. Specifically, we know that investors prefer strong portfolios. Our unrivaled footprint connects all the major North American supply basins with growing demand markets. It could not replicate our geographic positioning, nor reach today. Our healthy mix of businesses are structured to minimize the effect of multiple and varied market cycles.
Next we know that stable, reliable cash flows are important for investors as well. As we told you back in February, 99% of Spectra Energy's EBITDA for the 2015 to 2017 period will come from our fee-based business, and our DCF forecast is virtually unexposed to incremental commodity downside. And SEP is fairly unique in the MLP space, as 95% of U.S. Transmission revenues, the largest component of SEP and Spectra Energy for that matter, is reservation based with no commodity nor volume exposure. The average remaining contract term within our gas pipeline business is about 9 years. And the Express crude pipeline has an average contract term of 10 years, thanks to the contract restructuring we've done since acquiring this system in 2013.
Investors see companies with robust growth profiles and again, we're making great progress on our Drive to 35. By 2020, we'll grow our EBITDA by about $1 billion and approximately $800 million at Spectra Energy and SEP, respectively. That the projects that we have in execution are moved into service and begin generating cash. And with the ongoing growth and the demand for natural gas and natural gas infrastructure, we have tremendous confidence in realizing our projects in development.
Healthy financials are also important and we have the financial flexibility to efficiently fund our growth projects and pursue new opportunity. We have 2 solid currencies, strong investment grade balance sheet and disciplined financial management. Investors look for strong track record and proven performance and you've heard me talk about our execution advantage, unlike another feature that sets us apart. Since 2007, we've delivered more than 70 projects into service for capital expansion investment of about $9 billion, a record that speaks to our level of accountability and achievement.
Lastly and most importantly, investors want attractive returns and Spectra Energy has done that. In the past 5 years, our annual dividend per share has grown from $1 to $1.48, and we're committed to continuing to grow Spectra Energy's dividend by at least $0.14 per share through 2017. Similarly, SEP has delivered 31 consecutive quarters of distribution growth and we're committed to continuing that track record with an 8% to 9% annual growth rate through 2017.
So those are the attributes that differentiate Spectra Energy and SEP from other energy companies, and why we believe so strongly that both entities offer a best-in-class investment opportunity today.
With that, let me turn things over to Julie to take your questions on the quarter.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. And so now, we're now going to open up the lines for our question. Angel, would you please provide instructions on how folks can ask these questions.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christine Cho.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Christine Cho.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So some questions on SEP and the strength we're seeing there. You guys talked about in the release how the increase in quarter results were mainly due to 3 projects. The TEAM projects were put on September and November of last year, I think. So we've alre
componenttext: So some questions on SEP and the strength we're seeing there. You guys talked about in the release how the increase in quarter results were mainly due to 3 projects. The TEAM projects were put on September and November of last year, I think. So we've already seen 1 or 2 full quarters from these assets, yet the beats in earlier quarters were nothing like they are today. So did the reservation payments for these assets not all come on day 1, or are they are ramping up through the year? Any color on how we should think about that -- these assets and maybe your other pipeline projects that are supposed to come online in the future would be helpful.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll -- you're right. There is some ramp up, so TEAM 14, TEAM South, the Kingsport project as well, didn't have a quick start up until ramp up and revenues until the end of the year. And I think a little bit better results on the New Jersey-New York
componenttext: Sure. I'll -- you're right. There is some ramp up, so TEAM 14, TEAM South, the Kingsport project as well, didn't have a quick start up until ramp up and revenues until the end of the year. And I think a little bit better results on the New Jersey-New York project as well than we expected. I think, through the rest of the year, call it $5 million maybe $10 million on the projects that we brought in early, will be helpful, Christine, for the rest of the year as well.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of going off that, when we look at your SEP guidance, even if we were to keep EBITDA flat from second quarter and third quarter and fourth quarter, you guys would still come in $80 million over guided. Given you still have so
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of going off that, when we look at your SEP guidance, even if we were to keep EBITDA flat from second quarter and third quarter and fourth quarter, you guys would still come in $80 million over guided. Given you still have some projects coming online the remainder of this year and we actually still have a winter to go through, would it be fair to say that your guidance is very conservative? Or am I missing something that may provide some offsets in the second half of this year?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, Christine, we don't change -- we come out with our numbers at the start of the year. I think, historically, if you look at the last few years that we've been doing DCF, we've typically under promised than over delivered. But you still d
componenttext: Well, as you know, Christine, we don't change -- we come out with our numbers at the start of the year. I think, historically, if you look at the last few years that we've been doing DCF, we've typically under promised than over delivered. But you still do have 2 quarters to go. And, of course, well it wouldn't have affected first SEP that much in the first half of the year, the good strong, cold winter was also helpful in some regards in terms of additional interruptible revenues. So I'm not changing the forecast, but I think history would say, we do try to under promise and over deliver.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given most of this, most of your cash flow is fee-based than take or pay, how should we think about a distribution increase above guidance or holding it to maybe fund some of your projects?
componenttext: Given most of this, most of your cash flow is fee-based than take or pay, how should we think about a distribution increase above guidance or holding it to maybe fund some of your projects?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's the balance. It's interesting because, I know, historically, and I've chatted about this, some people may have had faster growth than us. But I think our kind of, call it 8% to 10% outlook on distribution growth and, frankly, on divide
componenttext: Yes. I think that's the balance. It's interesting because, I know, historically, and I've chatted about this, some people may have had faster growth than us. But I think our kind of, call it 8% to 10% outlook on distribution growth and, frankly, on dividend growth in that range, is the way to think about it. And I think, you see companies actually with large dividend growth and distribution growth has actually moved up, you're seeing actually other companies come down to a number more in line with ours. So we look at dividend policy and distribution policy on a regular basis, but really make decision on an annual basis towards the end of the year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Christine. This is Pat. I think one thing you know is that you can't levelize things like maintenance CapEx during the year. So, for example, we've been averaging about 60% to 70% of our maintenance CapEx in the third and fourth quarters. So we're no
componenttext: Hey, Christine. This is Pat. I think one thing you know is that you can't levelize things like maintenance CapEx during the year. So, for example, we've been averaging about 60% to 70% of our maintenance CapEx in the third and fourth quarters. So we're not changing our outlook for maintenance, but we're just saying, remember, that there's a ramping up in the last half of the year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just in the Western Canadian segment, obviously, the producers up there exposed to the Edmonton propane prices must be struggling with net backs. I've seen data that indicated that the frac spread in Canada is actually not that much
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in the Western Canadian segment, obviously, the producers up there exposed to the Edmonton propane prices must be struggling with net backs. I've seen data that indicated that the frac spread in Canada is actually not that much different from the U.S. due to lower AECO prices and natural gasoline prices that are higher in Canada, which surprised me a bit. Is that right? And as we think...

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I can say, I think, that's fair comment. I would say, you don't have as liquid a market out there, a. B, you've got -- you did affect in propane prices some infrastructure issues [indiscernible] changes. I guess the point I would make is that rememb
componenttext: Well, I can say, I think, that's fair comment. I would say, you don't have as liquid a market out there, a. B, you've got -- you did affect in propane prices some infrastructure issues [indiscernible] changes. I guess the point I would make is that remember, the Empress business is very much a Conway business. So it wouldn't get -- at least, with respect to our business, wouldn't focus too much on Edmonton as opposed to what's going from a Conway perspective.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I was more thinking about the outlook for GNP. What that would do -- what that's doing to the rig activity in Western Canada in reaction to the prices? And also, if you've heard about any solutions that are being talked about for propane in the regi
componenttext: Well, I was more thinking about the outlook for GNP. What that would do -- what that's doing to the rig activity in Western Canada in reaction to the prices? And also, if you've heard about any solutions that are being talked about for propane in the region, I've heard of some potential LPG exports in Western Canada or off the coast of Washington, do you think either of these could happen or too much regulatory red tape?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, I don't think it's regulatory red tape too much. I actually think, it's volumes. Remember, Western Canada produces about as much liquids as the entire industry as DCP would produce. So you need a lot of volume and at depressed NGL prices, I thin
componenttext: Actually, I don't think it's regulatory red tape too much. I actually think, it's volumes. Remember, Western Canada produces about as much liquids as the entire industry as DCP would produce. So you need a lot of volume and at depressed NGL prices, I think it's kind of tough from that perspective. That being said, I think June had the highest production out of Western Canada in a very long time, I think, 13 or 14 Bcf. And while you're right, you're seeing rig counts come off, you are still seeing a lot of gas being produced. And I think you see that affect hitting our pipeline business, which is, as you know, is a very long-term fee-based contract perspective. And I'm not sure many people would have predicted that Spectra Energy would added $1 billion in pipeline projects this year into our backlog out of Western Canada. And I think that you're going to have ebb and flows between GNP and from pipelines, but investors in the E&P business are going to be happy that the producers have pipelines that can take gas down to the Pacific Northwest and Alberta. So a lot of solutions being worked out, but I don't see huge NGL solution in the near term in Western Canada.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Last question for me, can you remind us how exactly the fee-based GNP model works in Western Canada? It's fee-based, but is there exposure to volumes? Or is there some sort of demand payment that also needs to get paid as the contracts for a
componenttext: Okay, great. Last question for me, can you remind us how exactly the fee-based GNP model works in Western Canada? It's fee-based, but is there exposure to volumes? Or is there some sort of demand payment that also needs to get paid as the contracts for a certain number of years? So is there recontracting risk? Some detail about that would be helpful.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So you should think of it very much as like negotiated pipeline rights in the United States. So we signed up contracts, 4 processing plants, long-term contracts, I think like the Dawson project that we put in place a couple of years was a 20-year co
componenttext: Sure. So you should think of it very much as like negotiated pipeline rights in the United States. So we signed up contracts, 4 processing plants, long-term contracts, I think like the Dawson project that we put in place a couple of years was a 20-year contract with a set fee that it's not volume risk. In other words, unlike you often see GNP in the United States, it's not volume risk. Now at the end of contract life, just like on a pipeline in the United States or Canada, you are exposed to recontacting. So that's obviously, that's something you're always looking at. But I think, our average contract life would be 3 to 5 years for the overall whole portfolio and as I said projects like Dawson, more like 20 years. So think of it much more like a negotiated rate pipeline as opposed to just cost of service.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Darren Horowitz with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Darren Horowitz with Raymond James.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, a couple of quick questions for you. The first on the 2 Appalachian expansion projects that you discussed. Just given the recent shift in basin dynamics and not only the E&P imbalanced between supply growth and demand, but a lot of the pipe options
componenttext: Greg, a couple of quick questions for you. The first on the 2 Appalachian expansion projects that you discussed. Just given the recent shift in basin dynamics and not only the E&P imbalanced between supply growth and demand, but a lot of the pipe options out of the region and the impact on regional pricing differentials may be shifting economics or, at least net back incentives. I'm just wondering if anything has changed from a customer thought process in your perspective. Maybe a better way to ask the question is, if you could kind of quantify or give us some color on what a positive response to the OPEN season means. And then secondly, the one project that wasn't discuss was that Texas-Eastern Lebanon expansion project, and I was just wondering in terms of incremental CapEx to scale that project up, if there could be any opportunity for that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Yardley, questions are in [ph] especially since Yardley is in the room as well. But really, I would say, customers have the same message: get my product to a demand market, very simple; or get me partial on the trail. And so you've seen us
componenttext: Well, I think, Yardley, questions are in [ph] especially since Yardley is in the room as well. But really, I would say, customers have the same message: get my product to a demand market, very simple; or get me partial on the trail. And so you've seen us a put a variety of projects that not only might take gas and molecules a long distance, but actually to the next closest liquid point. So you will see the projects ebb and flow in terms of their size. I don't think there's anything, I mean, restricting customers from signing up. Sure, E&P customers are very focused on their cap spend and were they think commodity prices will go. But -- and I think, the Lebanon project, as you'll see on one of the slides that we put out of the $9 billion, we did put it into execution this quarter, Darren. And I would say, it's lumped in with the Access South and Adair Southwest expansion because they really are, in many respects for some different customers, achieving similar-type goals. So even in the way we're going to FERC and have those approved, we have lumped in as one project. So you continue to see projects morph. I think the underlying facet that's really critical and a real advantage for Spectra, we already have assets in the ground so we're going to -- and I hear a lot of discussion about reversing flows and stuff. Please, guys, we've been doing that for a number of years now. So I know other folks are starting to think and get to that. That's not novel for Spectra or its customers and I think that's why you're seeing some of the results that you are seeing. Bill, I don't know if you want to add to that?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no. I think, we're still seeing some pretty good interests in both the Marcellus and the Utica regions from producers. It's a little bit longer lead time than perhaps it was a couple of years ago but we have a lot of faith in these 2 projects, both Ph
componenttext: No, no. I think, we're still seeing some pretty good interests in both the Marcellus and the Utica regions from producers. It's a little bit longer lead time than perhaps it was a couple of years ago but we have a lot of faith in these 2 projects, both Philly and Marcellus to Market come to fruition at some point in the not too distant future.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the gating issue is, well, it's just -- I mean, look, to build anything these days is expensive. And I think that as always, in any good business relationship, there's a negotiation back and forth, and you've got to find the common ground where it
componenttext: I think the gating issue is, well, it's just -- I mean, look, to build anything these days is expensive. And I think that as always, in any good business relationship, there's a negotiation back and forth, and you've got to find the common ground where it makes economic sense for both parties.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that makes sense. Last question for me is just on Access Northeast and I realized, it's still under development and a little bit of a moving target. But when you think about the ultimate scale and scope of that $3 billion project and then you
componenttext: Yes, I think that makes sense. Last question for me is just on Access Northeast and I realized, it's still under development and a little bit of a moving target. But when you think about the ultimate scale and scope of that $3 billion project and then you reconcile that with a lot of the proposed consolidation in the area and maybe again, a bit of a shift in terms of scale and scope of some competitors' pipes. To your point and I actually agree with you, I mean, obviously, following Algonquin and M&N, gives you just from a footprint perspective and a right-of-way perspective, a bit of an advance but a little bit of a timing shift to you, obviously, from a regulatory perspective and certainly, that's not getting easier. But I'm wondering, just with some of the different proposed consolidation dynamics, economies of scale and what could come out of that area over the next possibly 12 to 18 months, how could that impact Access Northeast either at an ultimate scale scope from a timing perspective or from a further growth opportunity standpoint?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I don't think that'll change the time. I mean, as I noted, just volume increase we're seeing in terms of our deliveries to generators. I think -- and remember, this is summer where the challenge is really in the winter and we're already seeing
componenttext: Yes. Again, I don't think that'll change the time. I mean, as I noted, just volume increase we're seeing in terms of our deliveries to generators. I think -- and remember, this is summer where the challenge is really in the winter and we're already seeing 20%, 30% increases out there. I don't think there's that time if they want to keep the lights on. And I think the Eversources, the National Grids to the world, which represent, what's, 5.5 million of 6.5 million customers up there bill, I think they recognize. So I don't see big changes there. I would also say that doesn't take away from any other projects that are also needed out there. Remember, our AIM, our Atlantic Bridge projects are about LDCs, that's already in execution, well in execution. The other projects about -- the Access Northeast is about electric. Other folks, major projects being pitched, are LDC-related projects. So I think the dynamics don't allow for changes. I think, the dynamics that we're seeing more like additional projects that will be coming forth over the following year. So if you think that we've got, we have 16, 17, 18 projects coming into service. If you look at gas demand in North America going from 75 call it Bcf a day to the 100 Bcf, 110 Bcf a day in the next 10 years, despite what any brilliant policy might be coming out of various government officials, that will happen. And those -- most of that's going to happen in the Northeast and that's advantage pipeline. That's got to happen unless people are willing to let lights go out, get cold or at this time, you're going to get a hot stick in the Northeast.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: I guess, real quick just following on Darren's question. Access Northeast, the PUC process that is kicking off, what insight do you guys have into that? And/or how do you handicap it as far as an outcome here?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill?
componenttext: Bill?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So -- Hey, Brandon, it's Bill Yardley. We're really interested in all 6 New England states. There's an overarching statement. I'd say that we've got pretty clear authority in one state, Rhode Island, and the other 4 states are going through som
componenttext: Yes, sure. So -- Hey, Brandon, it's Bill Yardley. We're really interested in all 6 New England states. There's an overarching statement. I'd say that we've got pretty clear authority in one state, Rhode Island, and the other 4 states are going through some sort of process. We expect those processes to be very clear by years end. At the same time, we'll be preparing the contracts for the 7 utilities that we have -- that we're negotiating with. We'll be submitting those with each respective state. And then, of course, entering the prefiling process and then we're looking for those state approvals, as Greg mentioned, probably early next year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. That's appreciated. Sticking with the Northeast, Uniontown to Gas City online, 3 months early. I guess, the question is, what was the driver for that accelerated pace? And is there any read throughs to the OPEN Project or anything else that's
componenttext: Okay, good. That's appreciated. Sticking with the Northeast, Uniontown to Gas City online, 3 months early. I guess, the question is, what was the driver for that accelerated pace? And is there any read throughs to the OPEN Project or anything else that's happening in the Northeast?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, you're -- depending on where you're working obviously and I'll give our project execution team full credit. I mean, we think this is an advantage we have, very keen on local game as opposed to state or national games in terms of getting stu
componenttext: Well, I think, you're -- depending on where you're working obviously and I'll give our project execution team full credit. I mean, we think this is an advantage we have, very keen on local game as opposed to state or national games in terms of getting stuff approved and the delivery was there. On OPEN, obviously, our time frame is still the 1st of November, and I'm hopeful that we'll be able to do that early as well. Obviously, everyday, we can get that pipe in earlier that has benefits from a safety perspective, from an operational perspective and obviously, from an economic perspective in many cases, not always the contracts to ramp up early. But I will tell you, the customers that have got the projects, they like it coming in early back to the point I was making that anytime we can get their project the heck away from supplier into demand area, they'll take it all day long. So we're pushing as hard as we can. We obviously, have the very systematic approach to doing projects this is not a new area for us. We're talking half a century of building stuff there and we're going to take advantage of that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then just real quick, bigger-pictured question. Montney customers, you mentioned, I think, Greg, in your prepared comments that there's an interest in finding an outlet that's not LNG for obvious reasons. My question is, is that a permanen
componenttext: Okay, good. And then just real quick, bigger-pictured question. Montney customers, you mentioned, I think, Greg, in your prepared comments that there's an interest in finding an outlet that's not LNG for obvious reasons. My question is, is that a permanent solution, bringing gas to the U.S. instead of LNG, or is this just a temporary outlet from the Montney customer perspective?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll, no. What I would say, a bit of both obviously. We signed long-term contracts, cost of service base. I think, it's a combination of both a longer-term solution. Look, I will be surprised to see any LNG in the West Coast of North America definitely n
componenttext: We'll, no. What I would say, a bit of both obviously. We signed long-term contracts, cost of service base. I think, it's a combination of both a longer-term solution. Look, I will be surprised to see any LNG in the West Coast of North America definitely not going to happen before 2020 at this point in time, even if you saw approvals happen instantly, just the amount of work that actually gets done. So whether you think a 6- to 10-year solution is long-term or not, but I think you're talking about a while before those projects kick in. And remember, as demand grows across North America, the Pacific Northwest, Alberta production is often -- has been declining, so Western Canada is not a single market. And you're still seeing activity going on from a demand perspective in the oil sands of which much of the fuel they need to use is natural gas. So yes, I mean, there's no doubt the opportunity has been created by LNG deferment. But the amount of gas we're talking about is nowhere near the amount of gas that would be needed for LNG. So one is not going to replace the other, the LNG would just be incremental to that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Earl Lee.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had a question, if Congress passes the 2-year extension of bonus depreciations, could you guys talk a little bit about how that would impact Spectra's distributable cash flow?
componenttext: Just had a question, if Congress passes the 2-year extension of bonus depreciations, could you guys talk a little bit about how that would impact Spectra's distributable cash flow?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There sure seems to be a very growing momentum in Congress for at least one, and it seems increasingly a 2-year extension of bonus depreciation. So as you may recall, we wind out in our 3-year forecast. We see about $300 million in cash taxes in '16
componenttext: Yes. There sure seems to be a very growing momentum in Congress for at least one, and it seems increasingly a 2-year extension of bonus depreciation. So as you may recall, we wind out in our 3-year forecast. We see about $300 million in cash taxes in '16 and '17. You could take about $0.25 billion of that cash taxes in '16 and '17. So rough numbers that makes your coverage 20% above your dividend, so call it 1.2 range. And so, it's obviously, out of everything folks are looking at, that's probably the one that's on pretty good momentum. I don't have control over that, but I think the reality is that infrastructure builds in this country are critical and I think Congress, on a bipartisan basis, obviously, recognizes that and sees the benefit that have been out there. So yes, we'll be watching that closely as we go through the rest of the year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can we just talk about NEXUS a little bit? How much of the volumes, I think you're looking for B and a half there, how much the volumes they have contracted? What kind of tariff are you looking out there? And what kind of return are you going -- do you th
componenttext: Can we just talk about NEXUS a little bit? How much of the volumes, I think you're looking for B and a half there, how much the volumes they have contracted? What kind of tariff are you looking out there? And what kind of return are you going -- do you think you'll get on those volumes you have contracted.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if we -- I think, we're about 70% contracted. As you know, a big element -- an important element of that is the LDCs that are, I think, account for about 40% of the volumes. They're going through the regulatory processes, now those contracts have be
componenttext: Well, if we -- I think, we're about 70% contracted. As you know, a big element -- an important element of that is the LDCs that are, I think, account for about 40% of the volumes. They're going through the regulatory processes, now those contracts have been filed for approval. I think the project -- it's in that 8% to 10% range. Obviously, if we don't have the full volumes there on start up, it's going to be more at the low end of that range. And I think the volume's actually are about 1.2, Ted, in terms of what we're targeting on NEXUS. It could be up to a B and a half, but I think our base economics are on 1.2. Remember, that's unlevered after-tax IRR.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

The next one for me is just no commentary, I think I must have missed it in the prepared remarks around DCP, you sort told folks that you'd come up with some sort of, I think, solution around some the leverage issues that are happening up at the LLC [ph] along with your partner, PSX. Any commentary you can give us there?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, not much other than, yes. I mean, we're very much on line for that October timeframe. As you know, there's been a lot of self help there. I don't know if we fully disclosed this but there are a couple of hundred million dollars for the asset sales t
componenttext: Well, not much other than, yes. I mean, we're very much on line for that October timeframe. As you know, there's been a lot of self help there. I don't know if we fully disclosed this but there are a couple of hundred million dollars for the asset sales that already happened at DCP this year, that's helpful, about $70 million cost efforts. So the management team has done very good job to manage that. The liquidity's in place to take us to the end of the year or into that October timeframe -- well, within that October timeframe. So stay tuned, Ted. We continue to work on that and believe that given the partners' relationship ongoing cooperation, we're going to get there.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll wait and see on that. And then last one for me, you did open the door on the M&A, I think, in some your comments. Kind of, I'd love to see if you can just expand a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of types of assets on the market,
componenttext: Okay, we'll wait and see on that. And then last one for me, you did open the door on the M&A, I think, in some your comments. Kind of, I'd love to see if you can just expand a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of types of assets on the market, maybe bid asset spreads with your system, et cetera.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd be a little bit careful. Obviously, there's a whole range of stuff, Ted, obviously, from a lot of asset sales out there, private equity, all that kind of stuff. So it depends, I will say, from a selling perspective, we've been very pleased what w
componenttext: Yes, I'd be a little bit careful. Obviously, there's a whole range of stuff, Ted, obviously, from a lot of asset sales out there, private equity, all that kind of stuff. So it depends, I will say, from a selling perspective, we've been very pleased what we've seen, very healthy multiples on what we've sold out of DCP which were assets that weren't really key for us. So I'd say, maybe the best way to say is, look, the key is to expand the footprint where we can find synergies and to the extent we can you tax synergies, which allowed other folks have already played that card, we have not. So we'll be looking at that. I mean, I guess my fundamental belief is obviously, as we've doubled the size of the company in the last 5 years, doubling the size in the next 5 years is critical. And could you leapfrog elements of that with some transactions that may come to floor. But obviously, it's a bit of a -- it's not something you can plan on. It's not in our 3-year plan. We don't need to have that happen to hit our targets. But there's probably some people under stress and we aren't.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following up on some of the questions that have already been asked, on the industry consolidation, is there a limit on 5 for you guys?
componenttext: Just following up on some of the questions that have already been asked, on the industry consolidation, is there a limit on 5 for you guys?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. But there are so many big players, I wouldn't say a limit on size. I guess, my bottom line would be size is an important element longer term, but I wouldn't say, there's a limit on size. We've done everything. If you've looked at the history from call
componenttext: No. But there are so many big players, I wouldn't say a limit on size. I guess, my bottom line would be size is an important element longer term, but I wouldn't say, there's a limit on size. We've done everything. If you've looked at the history from call it $8 billion, $10 billion deals with West Coast, which was that's 10, 12 years ago to call it $1.5 billion on oil pipeline. So I'd say anywhere in the mix that most of all 4. But I wouldn't, I don't -- size is not the determinant, it's far more the economic, strategic and footprint expansion that we're looking for.

componenttext: Well, I guess, what I would say is that every transaction seems to come across our table. But I wouldn't go any further than that. I don't think there's any transaction out there regardless, in any company, that we don't look at whether or not they imply or not.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On then on Access Northeast, I thought I remembered you guys targeting definitive agreements by June 30. And with Kinder going ahead and putting their project into their backlog, even though it's not fully contracted and realizing that they do targe
componenttext: Okay. On then on Access Northeast, I thought I remembered you guys targeting definitive agreements by June 30. And with Kinder going ahead and putting their project into their backlog, even though it's not fully contracted and realizing that they do target a different customer base, is your project a go regardless of Kinder?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kinder is not -- yes, the Kinder project is not a determinant on our project. We're fine with a customer agreement. The issue is to get them approved by the PUC, that's the gating issue for us. I think it's fair to say, Becca, that historically, we w
componenttext: Yes. Kinder is not -- yes, the Kinder project is not a determinant on our project. We're fine with a customer agreement. The issue is to get them approved by the PUC, that's the gating issue for us. I think it's fair to say, Becca, that historically, we would have put a project of this nature already in execution. But because of the unique element of an electric distribution company, seeking approval for gas transmission capacity, which is not been done in that neck of the woods, that makes us a little bit more cautious. But I think you even saw it coming for the Kinder Morgan recent days that, in fact, it's not one of the other. Both projects are needed, and that's where we've been for quite some time as well.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understand. And then the last on DCP, just wanted to clarify that your stand hasn't changed that you would not put equity into DCP and that you would not have a reduction in your ownership stake, that you're not willing to do that.
componenttext: Understand. And then the last on DCP, just wanted to clarify that your stand hasn't changed that you would not put equity into DCP and that you would not have a reduction in your ownership stake, that you're not willing to do that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I don't see a solution as us putting equity in Spectra Energy equity whether it changes our ownership, that's always something that I've put on the table historically. We like the business. The issue is one of value, Becca. And I think with any
componenttext: Well, yes, I don't see a solution as us putting equity in Spectra Energy equity whether it changes our ownership, that's always something that I've put on the table historically. We like the business. The issue is one of value, Becca. And I think with any of our assets were portfolio managers and so if the value is greater to not hold it, then hold it then we do the right thing from that perspective. Historically, we've never found that's been the case.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones for me. Looking at the Atlantic Bridge project, it looks like the estimated CapEx has gone down to that $500 million from $650 million before. Is that a change in scope, or is that just refining cost? Or can you provide a littl
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones for me. Looking at the Atlantic Bridge project, it looks like the estimated CapEx has gone down to that $500 million from $650 million before. Is that a change in scope, or is that just refining cost? Or can you provide a little detail on that?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A bit of both. The scope would decline a little bit from our perspective. So therefore, that brought down the size. Obviously, we wanted to build for our customers and the customers that signed up when we got the critical mass in terms of contracts, we sa
componenttext: A bit of both. The scope would decline a little bit from our perspective. So therefore, that brought down the size. Obviously, we wanted to build for our customers and the customers that signed up when we got the critical mass in terms of contracts, we said go. So originally, we might have seen some more contracts on that. However, Elvira, when some of those customers couldn't make up their mind, we said go because we wanted to deliver for the folks that we already had in hand.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to the consolidation question, are you looking across -- would you look across hydrocarbons? That's #1. And #2, would you look at anything that would increase commodity price exposure at the SE level?
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then just going back to the consolidation question, are you looking across -- would you look across hydrocarbons? That's #1. And #2, would you look at anything that would increase commodity price exposure at the SE level?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Look, I mean, I think we've been very clear -- well, first of all, let's remind everybody that if you look at our 3-year plan, our DCF has virtually no incremental exposure to commodity prices. And we think that's a real value differentiator. And I th
componenttext: No. Look, I mean, I think we've been very clear -- well, first of all, let's remind everybody that if you look at our 3-year plan, our DCF has virtually no incremental exposure to commodity prices. And we think that's a real value differentiator. And I think you'll see that in the quarter. So obviously, we would -- we're very focused on anything we do to be largely in the vast majority fee-based, depending on asset that we might buy, if it had some small elements, which may not stand the portfolio from a long-term perspective of commodity, that's not going to stop me from looking at it. The issue is what you do it from a long-term perspective. I'll give you a good example, it really isn't commodity, but sometimes you do think that maybe it's not the perfect fit but turn out to be quite well. When we bought West Coast, Union Gas, which is still in our portfolio and we have well in excess of a couple of billion dollars of expansion projects for utility would expect on pipeline, that may not have fit perfectly but it's been a good generator. Meanwhile, other utilities that we held when we bought West Coast, we have sold those assets. So I think it's -- none of that would have stopped the big price of what we looked at on West Coast, which was really the pipeline operations that we liked in Canada. But the focus is definitely from a fee-based perspective.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just going back to DCP, the October timeframe, is that a timeframe where we'll get an indication of what the resolution will be, or is that when a resolution will be implemented by? And is there anything special about October?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just going back to DCP, the October timeframe, is that a timeframe where we'll get an indication of what the resolution will be, or is that when a resolution will be implemented by? And is there anything special about October?

componenttext: Most of my questions have definitely been asked and answered, but I was wondering if we can just do 2 little follow-up questions related to DCP. I realize you're not providing an update on the strategy at this stage right now. But you've been very resolute in the past in saying that money goes one way. Has that changed at all just given how bad the NGL market has been? Or can we still continue to assume that SE will not be injecting any capital into DCP?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we've been clear that we don't plan to put SE equity into it. We have supported it in a variety of ways, historically, and today. So I don't want to split hairs here, but as you know, over the next 3 years, we have forgone our right to take
componenttext: Look, I think we've been clear that we don't plan to put SE equity into it. We have supported it in a variety of ways, historically, and today. So I don't want to split hairs here, but as you know, over the next 3 years, we have forgone our right to take distributions that are available for us to take. So I don't want to -- it would be hard to say that's not as bleeding cash, not taking cash and I guess, we could have brought it home and given it back, a. So I think we do put cash in from time to time, the point is the company see equity in it, a. And b, we've also bought assets and that's worked out well. If they are fee-based, we own 1/3 of those NGL pipelines, which are really great assets. So I think I'd look at it that way. But yes, I would say that's no change in the position we have had historically.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay, cool. That's what I thought, I wanted to confirm and I realize it's splitting hairs there. But yes, specifically, SE equity is not going in. And then the second question, Pat. You would sort of talked about the perverse tax benefit as a result, and so you basically the more DCP you lose is effectively the better it is for you on a cash flow basis at least in the near term until you max out the tax benefit. But if there's any change in the Spectra's ownership of the GP, let's say, one of the solutions is somebody to inject capital, you find a partner and your ownership is diluted, let's say, down to 20% or 25%. Would that change your ability to continue to have that tax benefit? Or you would still continue to have equity method accounting and it would still flow through?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's the latter, Shneur. We still follow the equity method accounting. We've picked up our share at any EBITDA loss and then that would generate current cash tax savings. So to your point, it would just be proportionately less than it otherwise would have
componenttext: It's the latter, Shneur. We still follow the equity method accounting. We've picked up our share at any EBITDA loss and then that would generate current cash tax savings. So to your point, it would just be proportionately less than it otherwise would have been.
