headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners' 2015 third quarter results. With me today are Greg Ebel, President and CEO of both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today for our review of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners' 2015 third quarter results. With me today are Greg Ebel, President and CEO of both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners; and Pat Reddy, Chief Financial Officer for both companies. Pat will discuss our results for the quarter, and then Greg will update you on our growth opportunities and the progress we're making on our Drive to 35. And as always, we'll leave plenty of time for your questions.
Our safe harbor statement is contained within our presentation materials and is available on our websites. This disclaimer is important and integral to all our remarks, so I would ask that you refer to it as you review our materials. Also contained in our presentation materials are non-GAAP measures that we reconciled to the most directly comparable GAAP measures, and those reconciliations are also available on our websites. So with that, let me turn things over to Pat.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well thank you, Julie, and good morning. Thanks for joining us today. As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered solid EBITDA for the quarter. These results reflect the strength of our diverse portfolio,
componenttext:
Well thank you, Julie, and good morning. Thanks for joining us today. As you've seen in our news releases, both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners delivered solid EBITDA for the quarter. These results reflect the strength of our diverse portfolio, which is structured to moderate the effects of various business cycles and preserve the upside benefits in the recovery phase. Spectra Energy Partners' EBITDA for the quarter was $467 million, $66 million higher than the same quarter last year and ongoing EBITDA of Spectra Energy was $634 million, down $70 million from the prior year quarter. Spectra Energy's ongoing results exclude special items of $26 million, all at DCP, and primarily from the gain on sale of an asset. 
Turning to the drivers of our ongoing results by segment. Let's start with Spectra Energy Partners, where EBITDA was up approximately 16% quarter-over-quarter. That CP consists of our U.S. Transmission and liquids businesses, and is shown in the upper right-hand corner of Slide 3. U.S. Transmission delivered EBITDA of $401 million, up $49 million over last year. These quarterly EBITDA results reflect increased earnings at U.S. Transmission and are attributable to expansion projects placed into service in the prior year, TEAM 2014 and TEAM South, as well as those placed into full or partial service in the third quarter of this year, Uniontown to Gas City end OPEN, respectively. Both of these projects came into service earlier than expected, building on our lengthening record of excellence and execution. Our base business continues to perform well and I'm pleased to report that we have achieved a renewal rate of about 98% of our contracted revenue on the U.S. natural gas pipelines, which is an indication of the value of our underlying base business. 
The Liquids business reported third quarter EBITDA of $79 million, compared with $60 million in the prior year quarter. The improvement is attributable mainly to higher transportation revenues due to increased tariff rates and volumes on the Express pipeline. 
Let's move now to our Canadian business segments, which are shown on the left-hand side of the slide. While our 3-year plan anticipated a lower Canadian dollar in 2015 compared to 2014, for the quarter, the Canadian dollar was 14% weaker than our planned and assumed. As a result, the FX effect on EBITDA for our Canadian business segment this quarter compared to the same quarter last year was $14 million at distribution and $24 million at Western Canada or $38 million in total. As a reminder, about 2/3 of our currency exposure is naturally hedged at the net income level on an annual basis. 
For the quarter, the reduction in net income from controlling interest related to FX was $18 million. Distribution reported third quarter EBITDA of $70 million compared with $82 million in 2014. The decrease quarter-over-quarter was driven by the decline in the value of the Canadian dollar. The base business remained strong and excluding the effect of FX, distribution would have reported EBITDA that was higher quarter-over-quarter due to customer growth. 
Western Canada reported EBITDA of $117 million compared with $156 million in the prior-year quarter. The decrease quarter-over-quarter is due entirely to the effect of the lower Canadian dollar I mentioned previously, combined with lower earnings and interest. The risk management program implemented at Empress, including the hedges that we have in place, continues to support our view that Empress will generate cash of $30 million this year. 
Also as a reminder, our Western Canadian business, including gathering and processing, is fee-based with no direct commodity exposure or volume risk on existing contracts. We continue to monitor the current macro environment and producer activity in Western Canada as there have been slowdowns in some areas. We remain focused on continued prudent cost management to respond to the changing environment in Western Canada. 
Moving on to DCP, you'll recall that what we show here as Spectra Energy's EBITDA from Field Services actually represents our 50% share of DCP's earnings before income taxes, plus gains from the DP unit issuances. Excluding the effect of special items, DCP's year-to-date EBITDA on a stand-alone basis is about $500 million, which is an indication of the strength of this business even in the current market environment. For the quarter, we reported ongoing EBITDA from Field Services at negative $29 million compared with $63 million last year. The 2015 period excludes special items of $26 million as previously mentioned. The 2014 period excludes special items of $12 million, mainly due to a goodwill impairment. 
The decrease in ongoing earnings was primarily driven by continued lower commodity prices and lower gains on DP and unit issuances, if decreases were partially offset by asset growth, improved operating efficiencies and other initiatives. We're pleased with all of the actions that have been taken to strengthen DCP and Greg will speak more about that in a minute. 
So all in all, it was a solid quarter for both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners. Importantly, these results have us ahead of our expectations at this point in the year, and we expect to meet or exceed our full-year plan and deliver on the significant financial commitments we made at the beginning of the year. 
Let's take a look at our distributable cash flow schedules, beginning with SEP as shown on our Slide 4. SEP's stand-alone distributable cash flow for the quarter was $270 million, an increase of $23 million over the prior year quarter. The higher DCF was attributable to the higher EBITDA I previously mentioned and reflects SEP's significant organic growth, strong fee-based earnings and virtually no commodity or volume exposure. The quarterly or year-to-date results are consistent with our 2015 planned expectations to achieve full year coverage of 1.1x. SEP quarter of $61 million and $148 million respectively. In addition, SEP continued to grow its distribution with its recently announced 32nd consecutive quarterly distribution increase. 
Turning to Slide 5. Spectra Energy's distributable cash flow of $223 million for the quarter compared with $236 million last year. The lower DCF is prime attributable to receiving no distributions from DCP this quarter versus $43 million last year. Both quarterly and year-to-date results for DCF are consistent with our plan to achieve full year distribution coverage of 1.2x. 
SEP's ATM program continues to attract investor interest, and as a result, we don't anticipate accessing the equity markets through any vehicle other than our ATM program for the remainder of this year. For the year to date, SEP has raised $450 million through its ATM. We also have significant liquidity available across the company, totaling $3.4 billion as of September 30th. This financial flexibility gives us confidence in our continued capacity to successfully fund our growth projects in an efficient and cost-effective manner. 
We know that investors are interested in the credit quality of our customers so I want to mention that 90% of our revenues are contracted with customers who are investment grade or are secured by investment grade equivalents like letters of credit. Overall, our base businesses continued to perform well, generating stable and sustainable earnings and cash flow. Our financial results are ahead of our expectations, even with commodity and FX headwinds, and we have the financial flexibility to fund our growth projects efficiently while staying on track to meet or exceed our 2015 EBITDA and DCF objectives. 
As a result, we remain confident in our ability to deliver on the $0.14 annual dividend increase guidance we shared with you earlier this year. So with that, let me turn things over to Greg to talk about our growth opportunities and the progress we're making on our Drive to 35.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks very much, Pat and good morning, everybody. As you've just said, we achieved another solid quarter from both a financial and execution perspective. The results we delivered this quarter continue to underscore the strength and resilience of ou
componenttext:
Well, thanks very much, Pat and good morning, everybody. As you've just said, we achieved another solid quarter from both a financial and execution perspective. The results we delivered this quarter continue to underscore the strength and resilience of our portfolio of businesses. SEP has no commodity and virtually no volume exposure and Spectra Energy's exposure to commodity is limited to 1% of our forecasted EBITDA. In the current environment, this limited commodity and volume exposure, coupled with our track record of consistently doing what we say we'll do, are important risk differentiators for us versus many others in the midstream space. 
Our focus continues to be on operating our business safely and reliably and delivering on our growth and dividend promises for investors, in both Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners. 
You've previously seen this slide outlining our priorities. So let me provide an update on our progress. First, we're very pleased that the recent transactions initiated by Spectra Energy and Phillips 66 to strengthen DCP are complete, with the transactions closing on October 30th As we've said previously, the contributions made by the owners, along with the other initiatives underway at DCP, established a foundation for sustainable cash flows at DCP Midstream over the longer run. DCP quickly adjusted to the rapidly changing industry environment and continues to be extremely diligent in taking actions of its own to insure its longer term success. Over the past year, DCP has engaged in various self-help initiatives, including the sale of $200 million of noncore or underperforming assets, producing base cuts by approximately $70 million and launching the restructuring of its commodity-sensitive contracts, which combined with hedging, will decrease fee-based earnings. As an example, you may have seen the recent announcement of a 10-year renewal of contract with one of the largest investment grade independent producers in the Permian. This contract has been converted at significantly better margins from a percent of proceeds to 100% fee-based and covers approximately 1 million dedicated acres. DCP is on track, if not slightly ahead, of where they need to be to achieve their contract conversion goal of reducing 1/3 of its commodity exposed NGL length by the end of 2017. 
With the support provided by the owners, and DCP's own initiatives, it's our view that DCP has the ability to realize breakeven cash flows and make ongoing positive economic contribution to the owners at current commodity prices, while remaining well positioned to further benefit from industry recovery. 
This turnaround is significant and a direct reflection of all the actions taken to strengthen this must-run business. 
Next, completing our secured backlog and doing so on time and on budget continues to be key to our execution advantage. We also remain diligent in advancing and securing projects in development to ensure we deliver on our growth objectives. Finally, we continue to believe there will be industry consolidation opportunities and that could advance our value creation objectives and complement our business profile. 
With that, let me update you on the projects we have in execution. You've seen this slide many times before and it's a great scorecard to track the success that we've had so far in executing on our growth plans. Not only are we consistently demonstrating that our project development timelines and budgets are reliable but also that we're able to realize some upside from placing projects into service early. Our Uniontown to Gas City project began delivering gas to the Midwest on August 1st and was fully in-service September 1, 2 full months ahead of the schedule. Additionally, the first segment of OPEN was also put into service about 6 weeks ahead of schedule and the remaining portion of OPEN has a November in-service date. We're very proud of the track record on project execution and pleased with the growth that these projects offer our investors. Since our last earnings call, we've moved $1.4 billion of expansion projects into service. And by year end, that number will be almost $1.9 billion as we will place the 2015 Dawn-Parkway project fully into service, consistent with the originally planned in-service date. 
In aggregate, the expansion projects that will be placed into service this year, excluding those at DCP, will generate $135 million of EBITDA annually. These projects are fee-based, with no commodity or volume exposure, further adding to the stability of Spectra Energy's and Spectra Energy Partners' earnings and cash flows. 
Overall, 2015 will be a successful year for delivering projects into service and demonstrating our project execution advantage. Looking forward, our project backlog is almost $9 billion of projects still to be placed into service. As a reminder, all of these projects are underpinned by executed customer agreements. You'll also notice that about 75% of our expansion CapEx in execution, is supported by secure contracts with demand-pull customers such as gas, local gas distribution companies, further demonstrating the strength of our current project backlog in this environment. 
All of our projects in execution are proceeding well and are on track to meet their respective in-service dates. Here's an indication of the great progress we've been making since our last earnings call. We have filed 4 regulatory applications for several U.S. projects: Atlantic Bridge, Penn East, Access South, Adair Southwest and the Lebanon extension. In Western Canada, the Jackfish Lake, RAM and High Pine projects have either already been filed or will be filed this month with the National Energy Board. These projects represent about $1 billion of low-risk cost of service pipeline expansions. 
In addition, construction is underway on AIM, the 2016 Dawn-Parkway project and the Express Enhancement project and we are on track to begin construction on Sabal Trail next year. A significant milestone will be met on NEXUS later this month when the project files its FERC application. 
Let's take a closer look at NEXUS and the progress we're making on that particular project. Many of your are familiar with NEXUS but I want to take this opportunity to remind you of the scope of the project that we are jointly developing with DTE. The NEXUS project is a 250-mile 1.5 Bcf a day pipeline that will originate at Kensington, Ohio and connect with DTE Gas in Michigan. This path will utilize TETCO, DTE gas and vector pipelines. That project represents tremendous opportunities for customers to access gas from both the Utica and Marcellus and move it through markets in Ohio and Michigan, to the 150 Bcf a day Dawn storage hub, the second largest physical trading gas hub in North America and which is owned and operated by our own Union Gas. 
NEXUS is a key strategic project for us as it will ultimately connect Texas Eastern with the unit gas system, something we've been envisioning for our customers for many years. To complete the upstream path of NEXUS, we're advancing the TEO project, an expansion of TETCO, to offer customers greater supply axis and market connectivity by transporting gas on Texas Eastern to Kensington Ohio. We'll be filing our FERC application for later this month. As you know, downstream from NEXUS are the Union Gas 51. billion Dawn to Parkway expansions, which provide customers in Eastern Canada and the Northeast U.S. access to supply directly at the dawn on [Audio Gap]

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as I mentioned earlier, the first phase of the Union Dawn, Union Gas Dawn-Parkway expansion projects will be completed later this year. NEXUS is moving forward with the support from executing customer agreements with LDCs to demand-pull markets as wel
componenttext:
And as I mentioned earlier, the first phase of the Union Dawn, Union Gas Dawn-Parkway expansion projects will be completed later this year. NEXUS is moving forward with the support from executing customer agreements with LDCs to demand-pull markets as well as Marcellus and Utica producers. We've also recently find a number of interconnect agreements with industrial facilities and power generators that could connect incremental load across northern Ohio with up to 1.4 Bcf a day. Importantly, this demonstrates strong long-term market support for our root and the project and we continue to see increased production forecast for the Appalachian region. We have achieved several milestones in NEXUS this year, including the January approval by FERC to use the prefiling review process, selection of an EPCM contractor and securing pipe for the project and as mentioned, NEXUS will file its FERC application later this month and we would expect FERC to issue its approval to proceed in the second half of '16, thereby allowing us to achieve our in-service date of late 2017. 
So we're pleased with the progress we're making on NEXUS as well as the progress we continue to make in all of our projects in execution. When this backlog of projects is in-service along with the others, we'll place them into service this year, investors can expect these projects to generate about $1 billion of EBITDA by 2020. 
Let's now shift our focus to projects in development. In addition to our backlog of projects in execution, we've got a robust portfolio of opportunities and development that will lead to continued growth in 2018 and beyond, and we're working diligently towards advancing those projects. We continue to make progress on our Access Northeast project, which is an expansion of our Algonquin system to serve the New England power generation markets and address electric reliability concerns during peak periods. 
This reliability is becoming a more critical concern each year as additional coal, oil and nuclear plants are announcing retirements. Key to Access Northeast is recognizing the importance of being directly connected to 60% of New England's gas-fired electric generators gas deliveries to electric generators can only be guaranteed for those with the last mile firm transportation contracts. Electric generators without last mile firm transportation contracts have no guarantees of gas deliveries on peak demand days, regardless if firm contracts may have another pipeline. Access Northeast will largely solve this issue. Earlier this week, we filed with FERC to use the prefiling review process for this project. At the state level, we are at a positive turning point to support for our approach and for the electric distribution companies to secure capacity continues to build with a series of separate but very consistent actions across the different states. 
Rhode Island's Affordable Clean Energy Security Act of 2014 authorizes the division of public utilities and carriers and the office and energy resources to develop an issue of open and competitive solicitations for infrastructure projects in clean energy resources. Last month, in Massachusetts, the Department of Public Utilities confirmed its legal authority to review and approve EDC contracts to enhance electric reliability and reduce energy costs. The main PUC's ongoing proceedings has recognized the benefit of examining a regional electrical lability solution for main customers. Connecticut continues to make progress toward their RP, focused on ensuring electric reliability as outlined in legislation passed and in New Hampshire, the PUC staff has issued a report supporting the legal authority for EDCs to enter into gas pipeline capacity contracts. We've made significant progress since the region's governors came together around the reliability challenge they identified in 2013. We're optimistic that before the year is over, some of the electric distribution companies will be filing contracts for state approval. As a result, with all this positive momentum, we're now even more confident in our ability to move Access Northeast into execution in the first half of 2016. 
We continue to actively pursue many other projects in development and have ongoing productive discussions with potential customers. Interest remains strong in many of these projects, particularly those that are demand-pull. Supply-pushed discussions are proceeding at a slower pace in the current market environment. However, we remain confident that this infrastructure is needed and will ultimately be secured by the end of the decade. 
We will continue to actively engage with the market as the energy environment involves and aggressively pursue the other projects in development. Two years ago, our Drive to 35 originated from our expectation that we have the ability to secure contracts and pursue organic growth projects totaling $35 billion. To date, we've been very successful on our efforts with almost $10 billion in-service and delivering cash and almost $9 billion remaining in our secured project execution backlog, which will add incremental cash flow beyond the current period. We will continue to focus our efforts on organic growth since it's the most economically attractive way to grow, albeit often at a slower pace. We're not dependent on M&A to achieve our Drive to 35. However, the current environment may provide good opportunities to participate in industry consolidation, which could in fact expedite our efforts to achieve that goal. 
So we continue to deliver solid results, further proof of the resiliency of our underlying businesses and continued demonstration of our execution advantage. As I mentioned last quarter, not only do we believe that investors are beginning to differentiate between investment options in this environment but also that Spectra Energy and SEP offer best-in-class investment opportunities. Spectra Energy Partners is one of the lowest risk MLP investments available, offering investors visible growth. The average remaining contract term within our gas pipeline business is about 9 years and these are reservation-based contracts. An Express crude pipeline has an average contract term of 10 years, revenues at our reservation base with no commodity exposure and virtually no volume exposure, allowing us to provide quarterly distribution growth for investors every quarter for the last 8 years. And we're committed to continuing that track record with 8% to 9% annual growth. 
Simply put, SEP is the most prudent, steady large pipeline MLP in existence today. Spectra Energy offers an unrivaled footprint that connects all of the major North American supply basins with demand markets, its first and last mile advantage. With more than 1/2 its EBITDA coming from SEP stable and reliable earnings, 99% of Spectra Energy's EBITDA for 2015 to '17 period will come from our fee-based business. There's virtually no further commodity downside to our DCF forecast if commodity prices move slower. As such, we remain committed to growing Spectra Energy's annual dividend by $0.14 per share through 2017. 
We have the financial flexibility to efficiently fund our impressive backlog of secured growth projects and pursuing new opportunities. We get two strong currencies for Spectra Energy shares and Spectra Energy Partners. Both companies have investment grade balance sheets, which we're committed to and we are disciplined in our financial management. So those are the attributes we believe differentiates Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners from other energy companies and while we believe so strongly that both our companies offer best-in-class low risk investment opportunities today. With that, let me turn things over to Julie so that we can take your questions.

componenttext: At 1.5, we're about 60%, 65% firm contracts all wrapped up. 1.4 Bcf of potential market along the pipeline route and it's kind of why we picked this route. We've got 4 generators we're talking to that they total about 3,000 megawatts net of the another half of Bcf on top of that, so really good load there.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's no doubt it's going to change over the 6 to 12 months. I think what you're seeing is starting to see some real differentiation. I just look at SEP equity, for example, on the last 12 months, SEP equity, I don't think it should have but backe
componenttext: Well, there's no doubt it's going to change over the 6 to 12 months. I think what you're seeing is starting to see some real differentiation. I just look at SEP equity, for example, on the last 12 months, SEP equity, I don't think it should have but backed up the yield maybe 100, 125 basis points but you see a lot of others moving 200, 300, 400, 500, even 600 basis points on their yield. I think that's going to make it very tough for some of those people to be able to execute on some of their plans and so I think that could create some opportunity for us. Obviously, I think part of our interest is on the liquid side. Marley's open to gas. That's our base business. So I don't think the delta between the has come down entirely yet but again as each quarter goes on and people see the strength of those people with the pipeline assets like we have that have very steady, reliable and have committed to 8%, 9% type growth, that's going to be rewarded versus some folks who have maybe much loftier suggestions that people are going to realize in this environment as not possible. I think you're going to see strength to go to people of size and strength to go to people of low volatility than I think that's advantage for both Spectra and Spectra Energy Partners.

componenttext: One thing I'd add to that, I think you summed it up well. And that's probably the extent of any type of conversation we have in the competitive landscape. They just know that we can get the gas exactly to where it's needed.

And so that was a critical component and now the other one, I will just turn around getting contracts regulators, which as I think we made an opening comments we expect to see some of those folks do that before the end of the year.

componenttext: Just on some of these smaller projects that we look at, whether it's a partial conversion of your gas line to a products line, or if it's an enhancement to Express pipeline, the $135 million sort of capital you're putting there, what type of -- how are these sort of brownfield projects where you're talking about more of a liquids component versus gas, which we can look at the FERC documents and figure out those increased tariffs and what they mean for returns on those capital. What do those returns look like on the sort of conversions to liquid lines or expansion to liquid lines?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, in both cases, you're talking about double-digit type returns, obviously with far less capital being put to work. Think about it like adding compression to a gas pipeline obviously, it's cheaper than providing pipe. So you're seeing the same thing o
componenttext: Well, in both cases, you're talking about double-digit type returns, obviously with far less capital being put to work. Think about it like adding compression to a gas pipeline obviously, it's cheaper than providing pipe. So you're seeing the same thing on the enhancement side, relatively small increments, I think the Express enhancement, that's about 20,000 barrels so it's not huge. But obviously, people will pay a lot to move product anywhere at this point in time and you're obviously, attracting that full rate for a relatively small incremental capital. So typically small projects, while they are by definition small, provide very good returns relative to large brownfield or obviously, greenfield projects, which are high single-digit type projects.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last question, on procurement of pipeline and steel and those sort of things. I mean, what are you seeing right now in the market? I mean, how much are costs coming down and so where are we in this cycle? Are those costs being passed through on lowe
componenttext: Okay. Last question, on procurement of pipeline and steel and those sort of things. I mean, what are you seeing right now in the market? I mean, how much are costs coming down and so where are we in this cycle? Are those costs being passed through on lower steel HRC costs?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's obviously a competitive world out there obviously, so any pipeline savings we get, they may help beyond one project but by the next project, they have the same competitive makeup so it quickly dissipates. But that being said, we're taking advan
componenttext: Well, it's obviously a competitive world out there obviously, so any pipeline savings we get, they may help beyond one project but by the next project, they have the same competitive makeup so it quickly dissipates. But that being said, we're taking advantage where we can on that front. And we are seeing some benefits on the steel front. I'd even say on turbines and things like that, but important to remember that the breakdown's about 70-30 for capital in terms of 30% is hard asset, if you will. 70% is labor and regulatory and land. And we're not seeing any pullback in costs on those fronts. People are building projects in highly concentrated areas. As we all know, regulatory processes don't get any easier. Land issues, labor is tight in those locations. You can move steel from one part of the continent to the opposite side but you can't move people that way. I think the savings, because of the relatively weak energy environment are not really showing up in full pipeline construction. You're getting some benefits on hard product but again, most of the cuts are on the other side. So we feel good about our estimates but I don't see us seeing big cost savings in this environment.

componenttext: First question, is DCP fixed? And what I mean by that is, if we sit here where the strip is, where it is may be volumes activity levels are unchanged, is there any need for you to do anything else there to have more capital more assets in, et cetera or can we kind of go forward as we are?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we've done again with the self-help, with the support of the parent or the parents, we're in a good position as I said in my comments where at these types of prices, DCP can be a cash positive business. So yes, I believe we're in a sustainab
componenttext: Look, I think we've done again with the self-help, with the support of the parent or the parents, we're in a good position as I said in my comments where at these types of prices, DCP can be a cash positive business. So yes, I believe we're in a sustainable position. Maybe just interesting for people to understand from a volatility perspective at DCP, a year ago, 50% of DCP's margins came from POP and people. Today, that's less than 30% and the biggest chunk of margin comes from gas and NGL fee margins. And that's a substantial change in a year and we've even seen about a 20% increase in the margins realized on gas processing on a fee base. So I think between, and we're still early days on the contract discussions but I think it's better outlined for investors in February at our conference. That was something we got on very early. And so yes, I think we've created a sustainable environment there for investors that won't require additional support from the parents.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Great. Good to hear. And then you mentioned a little bit about volumes in Western Canada and just noticing the processing numbers are down 12% year-over-year. I guess what's the outlook there, do we look like we're stabilized with where the activity levels are there or is there any downside and can you just remind us the contract duration that you've got there if you have any recontracting at risk around those assets?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember, two types of business there. Call it 1/3, 35% kind of pipeline business. So there's no contract risk in the pipeline side of things, so cost of service and that's where we're adding additional capital. On the G&P side, contract lives around kind
componenttext: Remember, two types of business there. Call it 1/3, 35% kind of pipeline business. So there's no contract risk in the pipeline side of things, so cost of service and that's where we're adding additional capital. On the G&P side, contract lives around kind of average 2 or 3 years and you always have some IT. I think IT runs about 10%, so obviously, from a revenue perspective, so obviously, you've got some downside risk there. As we go through and get our plans wrapped up for next year, that's exactly the kind of stuff that we're looking at if Contract renewals usually come up in the April time period. So that will give a view for how things are going to look from a longer-term perspective. Production of natural gas is going on and most of our assets are in British Columbia. As you know, and I think you do see obviously important infrastructure investments on the pipeline side and people still want to get their product out of Western Canada. So sure, challenging environment and we'll just have to watch to see how things go over the next year or so from a commodity price perspective.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then last one for me. You've taken on some partners on some of these projects, JVs and whatnot. Is that sort of still the MO as you move forward and move more of these projects that are in development into execution or would you like to keep whe
componenttext: Sure. And then last one for me. You've taken on some partners on some of these projects, JVs and whatnot. Is that sort of still the MO as you move forward and move more of these projects that are in development into execution or would you like to keep whether it's operational control or sort of full ownership of some of the projects you've got ahead of you.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we will always keep operational control. That's the modus operandi #1, and I would argue even strategic control but the partnerships are really critical. I think the partners that we've taken on and we have a long hstory of doing this, whether it's
componenttext: Well, we will always keep operational control. That's the modus operandi #1, and I would argue even strategic control but the partnerships are really critical. I think the partners that we've taken on and we have a long hstory of doing this, whether it's Exxon Mobil, Maritime's Northeast 10 years ago, or whether it's Sable with our friends at NextEra and whether it's in the Northeast with Eversource DTE. They all have really important insights as to what's going on locally. And that's where our competitive advantage comes. Would I like 100% of everything? Absolutely. Pigs get hogs, get slaughtered so from my perspective, we like that MO where we've got big sophisticated partners and we'll continue to do that.

componenttextpreview: Remember, things like ethane stuff sure our long-term contracts through '19, '20 so that's a big, quick different from the United States ethane is not done on a cost of service basis so that's a positive. On the other side, for the other commodities, real
componenttext: Remember, things like ethane stuff sure our long-term contracts through '19, '20 so that's a big, quick different from the United States ethane is not done on a cost of service basis so that's a positive. On the other side, for the other commodities, really when you think about propane and butane, we did put in some hedging last year and I think we're about 50% hedged for 2016, Paul. So again, as we go through the year and put the plan out, you can only go up about 12 months from that perspective. I would say that's an element of the exposure there but we feel pretty good to be 50% hedged for next year as well. Volumes through Empress have been better than we had expected for the year so that's probably margins lower volumes higher, which is why we've kind of been focused on this $30 million of cash generation in the year.

componenttextpreview: Pure demand really. I think just as we got through to the filings and confirmed what customers really needed and the way in which we structured the projects, that's remember from a cost of service perspective, that's the important element there. So as the
componenttext: Pure demand really. I think just as we got through to the filings and confirmed what customers really needed and the way in which we structured the projects, that's remember from a cost of service perspective, that's the important element there. So as they go into any be filing, you obviously want to make sure that you've got your costs locked down. If they have passed towards the end of the decade, but you are seeing some small LNG projects being approved with 5 or et cetera. Those actually as we look forward to be quite helpful early days, still quite helpful to the cell component of West Coast system et cetera. So beyond the dollars we put in to help out Western Canada in terms of the projects this year, call it almost $1 billion I think some of these small LNG projects would lead to additional pipeline opportunities, again on a cost of service basis.

CFE has a number of RFPs underway currently for pipelines in the northern part of Mexico there. Are you part of that process? What are your plans? Where are you in the Mexican exports?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to put out '16 and '17 here. I guess the only thing I would say is as you know, we were at 1 2 coverage at the FC level and that was with a low tax, cash tax in 2015. And we did not assume that in '16, '17. We'll get a good view
componenttext: I don't think we're going to put out '16 and '17 here. I guess the only thing I would say is as you know, we were at 1 2 coverage at the FC level and that was with a low tax, cash tax in 2015. And we did not assume that in '16, '17. We'll get a good view here I think in the next month from the federal government. I believe and I could get this wrong but I believe both separate committees in the Senate and the House have passed bills that we see the extension of bonus depreciation, one I think in the case of 2 years and one on a permanent basis. So obviously, that would have a very significant impact for us on a positive basis with respect to 2016. When we laid out the plans last year, we did not assume that and that probably runs $200 million plus in terms of the benefit, Christine so obviously, we're watching that closely and are optimistic that that in fact will be the case.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Bill Yardley. I would say Massachusetts and Connecticut, Connecticut's probably second in terms of sheer volume and then you get to Rhode Island, Maine, New Hampshire and lastly, Vermont. Our opinion is that these are moving really nicely as we'
componenttext: Yes, it's Bill Yardley. I would say Massachusetts and Connecticut, Connecticut's probably second in terms of sheer volume and then you get to Rhode Island, Maine, New Hampshire and lastly, Vermont. Our opinion is that these are moving really nicely as we've said and that I would say that Connecticut probably has sorry, Connecticut probably has the process that might take the longest because they're going through a state-wide process but it's shown the ability to really speed that up so they could be finished by early next year.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Lastly, this is just kind of a macro question, not necessarily about your assets but maybe just Marcellus buildout in general. We are seeing some massive dry Utica well and if this continues, I would think natural gas prices stay lower for longer, p
componenttext: Okay. Lastly, this is just kind of a macro question, not necessarily about your assets but maybe just Marcellus buildout in general. We are seeing some massive dry Utica well and if this continues, I would think natural gas prices stay lower for longer, possibly pricing out some producers who might not have that exposure. So maybe it becomes less producers each with more market share now. I would think some of the producers are not going to make it, especially given leverage and balance sheet issues. At what point should we be worried about some of the counterparties on all the pipelines that are currently being developed to get out of the region. I understand a lot of your build-out is underpinned by utilities but there is an element of supply-push out of the region so I would be curious as to your thoughts and maybe some insight into the landscape out there. Are there outs for some of these producers, if pipeline hasn't broken ground yet?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Well not on our pipelines, so if we sign contracts there, typically on the subject to our Board approvals and stock we have an execution has those Board approvals. So there aren't those adds. I'd say is a macro perspective, and maybe I'm just parroting maybe see some of that credit and analyst fixed income analyst Christine, what.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Producers hedges come off and credit facilities come due and the banks figure out what they're going to do, I feel okay about that. Again, as you point out, 75% of our execution projects in execution are demand-pull. And low prices producers don't like it
componenttext: Producers hedges come off and credit facilities come due and the banks figure out what they're going to do, I feel okay about that. Again, as you point out, 75% of our execution projects in execution are demand-pull. And low prices producers don't like it but the demand side sure loves it so that's a positive side of it and as Pat said, 90% of our customers are investment grade or secured. I think if you look at the U.S. side of things or the top 10 customers, which are investment grade except for one, would account for 50% of the revenue that we have and in Canada, the same type of thing and all of those top 10, which account for 50% of revenue would be investment grade. So feel pretty good where we are but I think next spring is the time to kind of watch things. But I would also say just like we see it at DCP and our prices and you've seen with the producers talking about it this week and last week, but they're ripping at costs straight, left and center and so you're seeing some pretty dramatic drops in what you wouldn't have thought was a possible a year ago is. So never underestimate the ability of necessity being the motherhood of invention here.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: But I guess, just to follow-up on that. Let's say a pipeline is primarily supply pushed, could it be possible that if some of the producers are having difficulties that that project might not go?
componenttext: But I guess, just to follow-up on that. Let's say a pipeline is primarily supply pushed, could it be possible that if some of the producers are having difficulties that that project might not go?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess it's -- I guess, that's a possibility. I think the issue would be -- so let's look at one realistically since it's already in-service, which in retrospect I think maybe a good look. So let's look at New Jersey and New York. So you're talking
componenttext: Well, I guess it's -- I guess, that's a possibility. I think the issue would be -- so let's look at one realistically since it's already in-service, which in retrospect I think maybe a good look. So let's look at New Jersey and New York. So you're talking about probably the pipeline that's delivering to until recently the most expensive place to get gas now that's New England. And two, the big factors of that pipeline, Stat Oil and Chesapeake. But you can say okay, well Stat Oil's very solid. Chesapeake is not investment grade today, but where they are delivering that gas is absolutely probably the most profitable piece of capacity that they own. So I think you can look at it just but where is it going, and if you do not have first mile and last mile advantage, even if you've got contracts, I think you can have some challenges with your supply-push producers. If you've got that last mile advantage, that's going to be the most important project and our capacity that they will hold. So I don't think you can look at it just solely on who's back in the project. Where is it going? And where it is going is that the mid-market premium demand market. That's the real value that suppliers supply-push players will look for even in a down market.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pat. One other thing we've already seen and perhaps could see more of if prices stay where they are is that producers that have credit issues sell assets from basins to raise cash. And in many cases, you see a stronger producer come in and acquire
componenttext: This is Pat. One other thing we've already seen and perhaps could see more of if prices stay where they are is that producers that have credit issues sell assets from basins to raise cash. And in many cases, you see a stronger producer come in and acquire those assets so we've actually seen already some upgrade in our counterparty profile in the basins you've talked about. And I think there's potential for more of that. So that's maybe an unintended consequence but in some cases, we get a counterparty credit upgrade as a result.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, my questions are more for Pat, I think. I'm just curious about the impact of lost cash flows given the asset DCP of Sand Hills and Southern Hills and the unit cancellation in the business. Just wondering how we think about that impact on SEP's le
componenttext: I guess, my questions are more for Pat, I think. I'm just curious about the impact of lost cash flows given the asset DCP of Sand Hills and Southern Hills and the unit cancellation in the business. Just wondering how we think about that impact on SEP's leverage, on SEP's leverage and then in terms of your reiterated longer-term dividend guidance, the distribution payment loss from MLP. I'm just wondering how you've kind of instructed us to think about resentment heavily on the ATM perhaps next year at the SEP level? And then how do we think about just the leverage target in general?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe starting with SEP, the way to math works is SEP is really indifferent to the removal or unaffected by it. Because we surrendered LP units. We have a giveback of a limited term giveback of our GP interest. And so as we look pro forma on the effect of
componenttext: Maybe starting with SEP, the way to math works is SEP is really indifferent to the removal or unaffected by it. Because we surrendered LP units. We have a giveback of a limited term giveback of our GP interest. And so as we look pro forma on the effect of SEP, it's neutral and of course, that had to be the case to get the special committee to sign off on it. So don't see any pressure at all on SEP. If anything, it's perhaps slightly positive as we modeled it. So I don't think it changes at all the credit profile at SEP or how we'll fund growth there for the U.S. portion of our CapEx. At SEM consolidation, there is a small reduction obviously from the surrender of units and the GP get back. But given where we are in the IDRs, it's not the full amount of the EBITDA that was transferred to DCP. And ironically, given the strong benefit to DCP of what we did and what our partner did matching with cash, I believe we'll be in a situation to see cash distributions resume at DCP much earlier than they might have otherwise, in which case we'll get half back, if you think about it that way, of the contribution that we made. So net-net, for a company on top that has $3 billion of EBITDA, very small impact and no effect on SE's outlook for capital or credit.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say the other thing, Chris, is as the years have gone on from what we laid out to people, I think you saw that in our press release, we've kind of looking at one coverage for SEP next couple of years. I think as we said in our press release, we could
componenttext: I'd say the other thing, Chris, is as the years have gone on from what we laid out to people, I think you saw that in our press release, we've kind of looking at one coverage for SEP next couple of years. I think as we said in our press release, we could see in that range of 105 to 115, which I think tells you that again, more plans are still being put together. SEP has added incremental projects and therefore, results for EBITDA going forward. Obviously, that comes to SE as well. So that's obviously, a positive from a credit perspective. Interest expense is it's staying lower and lower, so that's obviously, positive. And frankly, we've done better from a maintenance capital perspective moving some stuff into '15 and that's obviously going to help us because maintenance programs typically be multiyear projects in many respects and so moving some stuff into '15 given the results we have actually are helpful in '16, '17. That too is also credit enhancing. So we like the investment grade obviously committed to the investment grade and I think we're doing things consistent with that.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our debt-to-EBITDA in SEPs only 3.4x and we're targeting to be at 4 or below. So very good shape there consistent with our investment-grade rating and we don't see that changing. We're still -- outlook is 1:1 coverage at the end of the year but no
componenttext: I think our debt-to-EBITDA in SEPs only 3.4x and we're targeting to be at 4 or below. So very good shape there consistent with our investment-grade rating and we don't see that changing. We're still -- outlook is 1:1 coverage at the end of the year but not changing that forecast but I think it's possible we could do a little bit better than that at year end.

So are we just to think that that's going to be from an equity perspective, similar process as what you're thinking before or maybe just a touch higher?

componenttext: That's great. I just wanted to confirm that. And then when you think about I guess, some of the project inventory back lines I guess, to have a different take on Christine's question. If you think about counterparties in certain regions that maybe were part of the discussion, are you as ASP pressure maybe builds on them, any change in appetite or any mix shifts in terms of who's interested in some of the projects that are still in the development phase?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think as I mentioned, obviously, conversations on the demand pull side are very rapid and of great interest. Conversations on the supply push aside are slower and more cautious, perhaps less so on the gas side today, definitely on the oil side. Tha
componenttext: Well I think as I mentioned, obviously, conversations on the demand pull side are very rapid and of great interest. Conversations on the supply push aside are slower and more cautious, perhaps less so on the gas side today, definitely on the oil side. That's a very difficult discussion to have right now as people are just not certain where prices are going. We didn't have a whole lot, in fact very little in the way of oil projects until the end of the decade and infrastructures are still going to be be needed. So yes, you see it on the supply-side on the gas side but more so on the oil side. So but again, I'd go to where they're going to put their dollars when they have to for capacity is going to be with people like Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners who can get their product to the demand market. So again and you've heard us talk about this for years, last mile, first mile, last mile advantage is critical. Lots of people seem to have a first mile advantage from a supply perspective, but not having the last mile advantage, you're going to have a tough time filling up your pipes and if you did contracts with short term, 10 years or less, that's the folks I'd be watching. That's not what we did and those are going to be to tougher positions to find yourself in if you do not go to that last market. I think the supply push the producers are going to be looking for those types of contracts and saying, "That's not really taking me to a premium market, do I need to re-up or do I need to even continue forward with that type of contract?"

componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick follow-ups because there's been a lot of questions that have been asked that I was interested in but you put together a string of couple of good quarters where you've exceeded expectations. I was wondering if we can sort of talk abo
componenttext: Just a couple of quick follow-ups because there's been a lot of questions that have been asked that I was interested in but you put together a string of couple of good quarters where you've exceeded expectations. I was wondering if we can sort of talk about OpEx costs a little bit. With you adding projects, hard to parse the trends but we've seen some others where we've seen some OpEx costs come in. Is that an opportunity for SEP and SE on a go-forward basis? Could you see yourselves stripping out $80 million to $100 million worth of costs as you look forward over the next year?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Spectra Energy Partners, LP, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're always looking at that. I would say when you're adding $10 billion to your projects or to your overall base, it's going to be hard to see that number go down. But it doesn't go proportionately up. And in some parts of our business, you've seen
componenttext: Well, we're always looking at that. I would say when you're adding $10 billion to your projects or to your overall base, it's going to be hard to see that number go down. But it doesn't go proportionately up. And in some parts of our business, you've seen us take our costs in Western Canada obviously, you've seen us take out costs in DCP, but I would say I wouldn't look for a big reduction on the SEP side of things, and Union Gas where you're seeing the big build. So it doesn't proportionately rise but it's near it's hard for me to imagine you always careful on wages and stuff and making sure that they stick with inflation but we've gotten about $100 million of costs out of DCP and Western Canada given the environment there but I don't see that happening on the U.S. side of things. We're building stuff a, B, we're very focused on reliability. It's a license to build and operate. What can I assure you is wherever we can take out costs and where we're looking at things, things like procurement, obviously, a big issue, that's going to pay biggest dividends to investors and everything we can to get $1 off the price of steel or construction, that's forever return for Spectra Energy and Spectra Energy Partners. So always looking at costs. If we could whatever we can take out, we can, our cost increases from an O&M perspective stay well below the rate of inflation.

componenttext: Again, I'm not sure my interest was any different than it was a quarter ago. Maybe the market's actually showing some things that could be of interest. I wouldn't say it's any different and I reiterate, we don't need to do anything. That's the positive side but you would expect us as a good management team to be watching for opportunities, where folks have some particular weakness that we think is temporal and we can take advantage of where we are. But again, the base case is, the projects into service like we've been doing, $10 billion a project keep adding to the dividend, steady, steady SEP, SE, that I think will be rewarded by investors. In fact, I know it will be rewarded by investors and that is the prime focus. But as you've seen throughout our story, when there's some restructuring, M&A that's going to make a whole lot of sense, then that's something we'll obviously look at and I would say don't look for us to do anything outside the norm. If we ever did anything, we're a pipeline player, and we're a North American player. And so don't look for us to do anything different than that.
